PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of the survey released by the Business Council of Australia (BCA) yesterday showing that investment this financial year has fallen for two-thirds of manufacturing respondents and for half of other respondents, and that two-thirds of all respondents expect investment levels to be cut again next financial year? Is he also aware of yesterday's statements by the Council's Executive Director that `unemployment is going to get worse' and that `it is just wishful thinking to believe the recession will be over this year'? Finally, has the Minister seen reports that his colleague Senator Walsh has said that the so-called recession is arguably a depression and that the direct cause of this has been the Government's monetary policy? I ask the Minister: does he agree with the views of the Business Council and Senator Walsh? If so, will he now publicly withdraw his remarks of only last week that the worst is over?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The superficiality of the question is heightened by the last part of it. If Senator Short reads what I said last week, he would find that I certainly did not say that the worst was over.
—This article is not too superficial.

—Senator Short is pretty good at reading headlines; he should read the contents. If he read the contents, he may be able to ask a supplementary question which is phrased better than his original question. I did not say that the worst is over; I said that in certain sectors of the economy the belief was being expressed to me that the recession had bottomed.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the question as a whole, let me say that I have seen reports in the newspapers of the BCA survey and I have also seen the statements made by the Executive Director of the BCA. I must say that neither result entirely surprises me in the present circumstances. There are very disappointing conclusions, but they do not entirely surprise me. These statements made in the depth of a recession reflect conditions of an economy which is in a severe trough, and as economic conditions improve expectations may also improve. Business surveys about investment often reflect expectations about new investment projects rather than investment in committed projects, and intentions about new projects are more volatile than total investment. Nonetheless, I do not in any way retreat from the fact that overall, irrespective of any Business Council survey, investment intentions are weak.

I turn to the suggestion made by Mr McLaughlin that unemployment will be worse. I think that is a distinct possibility. Anyone who reads what I said in the newspaper article-and Senator Short waved the headline of it-will realise that I said that unemployment was a lagged indicator and the outlook would continue to be poor. In relation to the comment which Senator Short attributed to Senator Walsh, I have not read it although I saw that Senator Walsh used the word `depression' rather than `recession'. I have not read the statement that the recession, or whatever, was induced totally by Government interest rates policy. But if I had read it or if that quote were correct, then I would disagree with it.

A wide range of factors impact on the depth of the recession in Australia, apart from government interest rate policies. These include such things as the depth of the rural crisis in this country. Certainly, farmers have had a difficult time with interest rates, but the rural crisis has not been induced by interest rates; it has been induced by markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interest rates have had a fair share in it.
—Senator Panizza should listen to what I say before he gets excited. Let me put it another way: irrespective of interest rates we would still have a severe rural crisis in Australia.
—But not as severe.

—If Senator Walters knew anything about it she would know that was true. To say that the problems of the wool industry and the international market for wool are related to interest rates is absolute rubbish. That is the sort of rubbish that is spewed forth by Opposition spokesmen but it is mindless in the extreme. Quite apart from the rural crisis, a range of factors associated with corporate behaviour in Australia have done immense damage to the Australian economy and have reduced confidence.
—How about Keating's role?

—I said quite apart from that. If Senator Kemp listened occasionally instead of approaching every problem with an open mouth he might even learn something. I do not know whether Senator Kemp feels he is capable of learning anything after all those years in the think-tank but he is now in the real world, in the kitchen here, and he will not get away with that sort of rubbish with me. Senator Kemp might get away with it at some second rate Liberal Party branch but he will not do it here.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the last part of Senator Short's question, which allegedly attributes to Senator Walsh a remark that the recession was almost entirely related to interest rates, that is not correct and I do not agree with that view, if it is Senator Walsh's view.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know if you haven't read it?
—I am capable of answering the question, thanks. In respect of that matter, I just have a different opinion.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question in light of that answer. How much worse does the Minister expect unemployment to get? Am I correct in assuming from his answer that he does not agree with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that the economy will recover in the second half of 1991?

—Senator Short can assume anything he likes from my answer except that. I did not say anything about that at all. In so far as unemployment is concerned, I have nothing to add to what I said. I am not in the business of forecasting but I think unemployment will be a very difficult problem in the next few months and probably well towards the end of the year.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is it a fact that the National Farmers Federation (NFF) has $12m in its so-called fighting fund with which to mount legal campaigns against trade unions in secondary as well as primary industries? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether the NFF, if it is so well off, is using at least some of this money to help its members and the broad community to work with the Government and industry to promote Australian primary products overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to say with any certainty what amount of money the National Farmers Federation has in its national fighting fund. I see the figure of $12m referred to constantly in press reports, but I am not able to confirm whether that is accurate. For the record, I have never seen that figure-which often appears in articles that flatter the NFF-disavowed or denied.

ANSWER.PARA: The NFF fighting fund apparently grew out of the Mudginberri dispute and has been threatened to be used where the NFF has talked about its members going onto the waterfront in Australia. We understand from Troubleshooters Available that the fighting fund was used to help it in a major legal action dealing with the definition of `worker' in the building industry, seeking to have the classification of `worker' redefined as `contractor'. We know that, according to Troubleshooters Available, which is a privately-owned commercial company, it would not have been able to take that legal action without the support of that quite obviously healthy fund of the NFF.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won the case.

—It is yet to be seen whether it wins the case, because I understand that an appeal has been lodged. If an appeal has been lodged, no-one can claim victory until the appeal has been determined; I would have thought that was quite obvious. It is clear that there is great hardship in rural Australia. I am not sure that farmers who are members of the NFF would consider that contributions by them to a quite large fighting fund-amounting to maybe $12m-ought to, in the face of that rural crisis, be spent on ascertaining the definition of a `worker' for the benefit of those who build concrete and glass towers in the central business district of Australia. Maybe some farmers think that is the priority in this crisis, but I would be surprised if that was a universal view.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is concerned about problems in rural Australia. We have pledged up to $500m to the wool industry and up to $150m to the wheat industry. We have increased the rural adjustment scheme to $160m in 1991-92. We are mounting a huge diplomatic effort in the world to have the trade blocs, the export enhancement scheme in the United States and the common agricultural policy in Europe, done away with.

In my view, those things which open markets for Australian rural products are of a higher priority than this matter, which I consider to be a wrong priority for farmers. I do not know what a family on a farm in Australia which is facing hardship in the economic circumstances of today, because of the operation of those trading blocs in the world, thinks about its money, or money that could be spent in aid of its immediate needs, being spent on esoteric legal actions in the field of industrial relations.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EVALUATION OF TENDERS FOR COMPUTER CONSUMABLES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. I remind the Minister that he stated that one of the reasons he improperly intervened in the tender for computer consumables was because of the Australian manufactured content. Will the Minister confirm that all diskettes, with the exception of 5 1/4-inch diskettes, are fully imported? I have here a 5 1/4-inch diskette. Will the Minister advise what components of this diskette are manufactured in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the start, I rebut totally the allegation by Senator Parer that I improperly intervened in this matter. I repeat for him once again, so that he can understand it, that by my intervention in this matter two things have happened. First of all, we have now a list of eligible tenderers for government which provides items at a cheaper price than were provided on the initial list. So, firstly, in essence, the taxpayer wins out. Secondly, an Australian supplier, which has been able to use the Australian-made logo, has been put back on a tender, together with a number of other companies providing items at a cheaper price than those that have already been accepted on that panel of tenderers.

ANSWER.PARA: Those two objectives have been realised and I rebut totally the inference that there has been improper intervention. I am responsible for this area and if this sort of situation were to arise again, with those two motivations in mind, I would do the same thing.

Secondly, in the other part of Senator Parer's question, he made some statement about diskettes other than the 5 1/4-inch diskette. My recollection is that that particular diskette in itself came within the range that would otherwise have been included on the tender if a fair process and evaluation had been adopted at the start. So, for a start, that part of Senator Parer's allegation in respect of Nashua Australia Ltd is rebutted by the facts.

In respect of the other allegation, no-one has claimed that the diskettes have been made within Australia. However, I have consistently said that Australian content is involved in Nashua's production and, to that extent, Nashua as a company is entitled to use the `Australian made' logo.

I do not know why Senator Parer keeps on raising this question. He is on a loser and he has been on a loser from day one on it. Let me reiterate that we have advice from senior officers of the Department that the process, in which I took an interest, was one that could and should have been conducted much better and fairer in a whole range of ways. That was quite clearly evidenced by the documents that were tabled in here last week. Those documents and that advice from the Secretary of the Department and senior officers have not been taken into account by Senator Parer because he has an incapacity and a non-desire to actually address the facts in this case.

However, the outcome of the whole thing is that we now have on the panel a company which is entitled to use the `Australian made' logo. That company, in respect of one of those diskettes for which it is back on the tender, is price competitive. Those two outcomes are evidence that my involvement, the due conduct of my responsibility in this area, was well merited.

Let me ask a couple of rhetorical questions. The point ought to be made because it does show the difference between the Government side of the Parliament and the Opposition side. The reality is that Opposition senators come in here making accusations and claims but government is about hard work. Government is about actually taking responsibility and an interest in portfolios. So let me ask the rhetorical question: is Senator Parer saying that as a relevant Minister he would not have been persuaded by the fact that an Australian supplier had been unfairly excluded from this tender? Is Senator Parer saying that he would not have been motivated by the fact that companies tendering prices at cheaper than those that were accepted on the tender were excluded? Would Senator Parer not be motivated to take an interest? If that is the case, Mr President, it highlights the distinction. That is why the Australian Labor Party is over here and that is why the Australian people put us here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Firstly, would the Minister define what he means by `an Australian supplier' and, secondly, would he display a modicum of honesty for a change and admit that none of the components of this diskette are manufactured in Australia?

—I have already answered this question but let me restate it for the information of Senator Parer. We are talking here of a supplier of information technology equipment which is allowed to use the Australian-made logo, does so, has a component of Australian production in its operation and, as a consequence, is entitled to use that logo. If Senator Parer has some problem with that, let him stand up in public and say so. Let him stand up in public and say that he would not intervene on behalf of Australian suppliers-suppliers that are recognised as such. Let Senator Parer also go out in public and say that, if there was a system that he was responsible for, if that system did not produce--

—On a point of order: it is now a quarter past two and only three questions have been asked, Mr President. The Minister is clearly debating the issue and I ask that you pull him into line and let someone else have a go.
—Order! There is no point of order but we are not getting a lot of questions answered.

—The final point is that, if Senator Parer wants to take an attitude that he would not intervene as a responsible Minister, when quite clearly at the end of the day I was vindicated and the senior officers assured the Parliament and the Australian people that the tender was not conducted in a way in which it should have been conducted, he should stand and be tested on that.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister noted that the Conservative Party of the United Kingdom has introduced a fringe benefits tax like that introduced by the Hawke Labor Government in this country in 1985? Can the Minister inform the House of the benefits to Australia stemming from the introduction of the fringe benefits tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is timely to have a question like this. After all, the introduction of the fringe benefits tax was the cause of considerable concern at the time and a lot of wimpishness and backfilling by the Opposition-a terrible weakness of the Opposition parties-and, an election or so later, it decided that it was not a bad thing after all. Now, after a similar time span, the United Kingdom Government has decided to introduce a form of fringe benefits tax. It is good, of course, that some of these ideas are starting to penetrate the ranks of conservative parties. I hope that the process goes on-even here in Australia where it is a pretty hopeless task, one would think.

ANSWER.PARA: Since this Government came to office there has been a considerable broadening of the tax base and it is a much fairer and more equitable taxation system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are easily pleased.
—There has been a massive crackdown on rorts-something that will not appeal to Senator Crichton-Browne, of course.
—Why not?

—Because Senator Crichton-Browne belongs to the old WA Inc.-the one run by Charlie Court-and we have not caught up with that yet. There has been a massive crackdown on rorts. A lot of the hard issues, in terms of fringe benefits, capital gains tax and so on, have been tackled by this Government and the tax base has been broadened considerably. Capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax add to the purchasing power in the same way as ordinary income. The introduction of taxes on fringe benefits and capital gains was made because it was clearly unfair that ordinary wage and salary earners were taxed while others earning an equivalent amount in kind were not. Broadening the tax base has provided the opportunity to reduce personal tax very substantially.
—Why don't the trade unions pay tax?

—Senator Kemp would not know about this because probably he did not earn anything before he came here. The fact of the matter is that there has been an enormous reduction in personal tax under this Government, and company tax rates during this Government's term of office have been reduced. Company tax has been cut from 49 to 39 per cent, the bottom rate for personal income tax has gone from 30c in the dollar to 20c, and the top marginal rate from 60c to 47c. I should add that dividend imputation has provided a major benefit to incorporated businesses by reducing the maximum effective rate of tax on distributed company income from 78.4 per cent to 47 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: At the time, of course, all of these base-broadening measures were opposed by the Opposition for cheap political advantage. It was only in the Opposition's so-called economic action plan that it finally had the fortitude to enforce the fringe benefits tax. Perhaps it has been worth while because the Conservatives in the United Kingdom have now taken a leaf out of the Australian tax book on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen reports of condemnation of Australia by Mr Turgut Ozal, OA? Has the Minister received confirmation of the contents of Mr Ozal's remarks concerning Australia's human rights record? Are the remarks made by Mr Ozal factually correct? How does Australia's human rights record compare with Turkey's? If Mr Ozal's condemnation of Australia is confirmed, will the Government consider stripping Mr Ozal of his Order of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports attributed, if not to Mr Ozal, at least to his spokesman, but those reports have been filtered through Turkish newspapers as communicated to us through a wire service agency, so it is a little difficult to be absolutely sure as to who was saying precisely what and we have, as yet, had no precise confirmation of that.

ANSWER.PARA: The report that appeared in most of the print media and elsewhere this morning suggests that Australia had no right to criticise Turkey's human rights record because our prisoners were subjected to torture and repression with some 96 prisoners committing suicide each year due to torture and repression. To the extent that was said-and I repeat that we have no confirmation that it was-it is not an accurate statement about the situation in Australia. The Australian Institute of Criminology late this morning put out a statement making that very clear. It came from Mr David Biles, the Deputy Director of the Institute, who was head of research for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, in the course of which he was responsible for compiling very accurate and comprehensive information not only about Aboriginal deaths but also about all deaths that have occurred in police custody or prisons over the past 10 years. His conclusion from that study was:

. . . over the past ten years the average number of suicides in prisons throughout Australia was just under 14 cases per year. Furthermore, there is no evidence to suggest that any of these cases were the result of torture or repression.

As to the general question of the comparison of Australia's human rights record with Turkey's, comparisons of this kind in this context are a little invidious. I do not propose to go into any further detail on that subject except to say that there have been a number of human rights problems in Turkey over the years. They were the subject of some considered and extensive discussion in private between the Prime Minister and the President, in which discussion I and the Turkish Foreign Minister participated. They were the subject of some reference by the Prime Minister during the dinner, as most honourable senators would recall. Those references by the Prime Minister were sufficient to articulate Australian concern, but were moderate and balanced in character.

As I have also said publicly today, it ought to be acknowledged that the Ozal Government has made considerable strides, particularly in the very recent past, in working some conspicuous improvements in the situation, at least so far as the text of the relevant law is concerned. It may be that practice has some little distance yet to go. As I say, it is not helpful to engage in any further contrasts and comparisons; the points have been made sufficiently clearly.

As to the last part of the honourable senator's question-will the Government consider stripping Mr Ozal of his OA?-the answer is no. That award was given in specific acknowledgment and recognition of the very substantial role that Turkey played in the commemoration of Gallipoli. It was a gesture of appreciation on behalf of the Government and the people of Australia for the role that Mr Ozal and his Government played in ensuring that the commemoration was the spectacular and moving success that it was.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to reports this morning which suggest that unions completed voting last Friday on a proposal for an amalgamated white collar employees union throughout the finance services sector. Has the Australian Electoral Commission notified any results of the amalgamation proposal? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the significance of this amalgamation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not got a final outcome for the ballot overall, but the results State by State show an overwhelming support by the five unions that voted by secret ballot to amalgamate and form an Australian finance sector union. The five unions were the Australian Bank Employees Union, the Australian Insurance Employees Union, the Trustee Companies Officers Association, the AMP Society Staff Association and the Wool Brokers Staffs Association. All of those now appear destined to form one finance sector union in Australia. It will have a notional membership of 108,000. This is significant for the finance sector and union organisation in that sector. I congratulate the unions on what now appears to be the successful outcome of their ballot.

ANSWER.PARA: This will be a significantly genuine industry union in that it is located in the finance sector. I now renew the call that I have made frequently to unions that we encourage to amalgamate on industry lines that, in re-forming their new structures, they look at the proposal to form their branch structure along enterprise lines rather than along the lines of State boundaries, as has been the practice in the past.

We take some pride as a government in laying the legal framework for the possibility of amalgamations of this sort. Our commitment to the idea of union amalgamation arose from five major reports under several governments in the past-the Jackson report on manufacturing industry in 1975, the report of the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration in 1977, the Myers report on technological change in 1980, the report of the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems in 1985, and the Pappas Carter report for the Australian Manufacturing Council, The Global Challenge: Australian Manufacturing in the 1990s. All significant reports of Liberal and Labor governments in the past have supported strongly the view that we should rationalise our union structure in Australia. This amalgamation is an example of that.

The figures that I now have from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that, indeed, on 30 June 1986 there were 326 unions in Australia, both Federal and State. This figure dropped to 295 by 30 June 1990. Since then, amalgamations have resulted in 19 fewer Federal unions, with a further drop of between six and 30 to be achieved by 30 June 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in today's Australian which states that foreign dumping of canned foods is beginning to squeeze the $1.3 billion canned food industry and consequently threatens thousands of jobs among the country's most efficient manufacturers. I ask the Minister: in view of the fact that Australia now has an unemployment rate of 9.9 per cent and that the dole queues are expected to get even longer, and considering the high rate of employment that the canned food industries provide, will he consider urging the Government to freeze the tariff cuts until the current anti-dumping hearings are completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report-in fact, I scanned it briefly this morning-in the Australian which makes the allegation about the dumping of foreign canned goods in the Australian marketplace. As I have indicated before in answer to a range of questions from honourable senators on both sides, I am most concerned that Australian consumers have access to a range of food products, including imported food products, but specifically that they be protected from misleading and deceptive practices which lead them to make a decision in favour of overseas producers of food products rather than Australian growers and orchardists.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as dumping is concerned, it is absolutely clear that Australian producers have a right to be protected against unfair market competition. Indeed, the Government strengthened the anti-dumping legislation-and no doubt Senator Bjelke-Petersen supported that when it passed through the Senate in 1988-when we created the Anti-Dumping Authority. A review of the current anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements is under way at present. Quite clearly, a range of foods will be imported into Australia and, under State food law, all packaged foods must be labelled with their country of origin in order to allow consumers the right to make an informed choice about the origin of the goods-in particular the foods-that they buy. Recently the Government has taken action to stamp out the practice of imported fruit juice concentrate being processed in Australia and then labelled as a product of Australia. Under an amendment--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is answering a question about labelling that no doubt was prepared for him. But the question that Senator Bjelke-Petersen directed to him was about anti-dumping. He may not have a brief on anti-dumping, but he should not try to deceive the Senate by reading out the answer to a question on labelling.
—There is no point of order, but perhaps Senator Tate could be more relevant.

—Mr President, I am being relevant. The whole point is that the marketplace in Australia should operate in a way which is fair to consumers. I am agreeing with that point made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I have pointed to the strengthening of the anti-dumping legislation. I am also supplementing the description of how the marketplace should operate by pointing out that under an amendment to State and Territory food law-encouraged by me in particular-all packaged fruit juices and certain related products will shortly have to state the origin of all imported fruit juice ingredients on the label or state that those ingredients are imported. We are also requiring all unpackaged fish, fruit, vegetables and nuts to carry a sign showing the country of origin or the fact that the goods are imported.

ANSWER.PARA: In these ways, I believe that I am answering Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question, which concerned increasing competition from imported food products. In so far as it is unfair competition and involves the dumping of products, that ought to be addressed. In so far as it is fair competition, I believe that consumers in the marketplace have a right to know the country of origin of the goods that they are purchasing.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports suggesting that the Opposition would like to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission? Can the Minister inform honourable senators what effect such a policy would have on working men and women throughout Australia, particularly in industries in the private sector, and can he outline the benefits of reduced occupational accident, injury and death?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the Australian Capital Territory Industrial Relations Society meeting last week, the shadow spokesperson for industrial relations, Mr John Howard, said, among other things, that, should the Opposition come to power, it would abolish the Occupational Health and Safety Commission-that is, Worksafe Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say that last year in Australia, as a result of industrial accidents in the workplace or disease, just on 400 people died and about 300,000 were injured. The cost to the Australian economy of this loss of production, not to mention the human trauma and suffering caused by it, is in excess of $10 billion annually. If we compare that with the indicator for time lost in industry through industrial disputes, we find that time lost through accidents and disease in Australian industry runs at about 12 times more than time lost through strikes. Therefore, in terms of priority, occupational health and safety certainly commands national attention on a major scale.

Worksafe Australia is an agency of the Federal Government. It is chaired by a distinguished figure from the private sector, Mr Lou Marks, who was a chief executive officer of Brambles and, before that, Mayne Nickless Ltd. He is a recognised leading business person in his field, uniquely equipped to chair the tripartite body, Worksafe Australia, which contains representatives, as well as of the Commonwealth, of all State governments, of unions and of employers.

It is a consensus body that works, as all parties admit, on the basis that there is a need to find a tripartite view on reducing the level of accidents and disease in Australian industry. It works extremely well. All States, irrespective of political persuasion, recognise the need for Worksafe to remain, the need in Australia for us to achieve common national standards for safety and accident prevention in the workplace. Common national standards would certainly help major national companies in this country, as well as helping potential investors in industry to know exactly what the accident safety regime would be.

Currently, Worksafe is dealing with a number of major causes of lost time in industry. It is conducting studies particularly on occupational back pain, noise-induced hearing loss, occupational skin disorders and injuries arising from the operation of mechanical equipment. It has conducted a recent study on chemicals in the workplace, and it is setting up a national commission, which will now oversee the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme for hazardous chemicals in the Australian workplace.

The recent work of Worksafe Australia received international acclaim and respect. That study was refereed on a world level by distinguished authorities in other countries. Carried out over six years by Worksafe Australia, published and launched by me, I am pleased to say, it defined the damage caused by white asbestos in industry. It made a significant connection between white asbestos and the disease, mesothelioma. Once this disease is diagnosed, there is no cure for it and the recipient dies. As a consequence of that international study, there is now a possibility of people with mesothelioma, for which there is no cure, to at least achieve some dignity in their death and receive compensation for the disease they have suffered. It was a world-class study, and it received major national attention.

I am entirely disappointed that an opposition would think it could appeal to the Australian electorate by running on a platform of abolishing such an important agency in terms of the health of Australian workers in the workplace and industry in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which concerns Cambodia, is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's assessment of the apparent cease-fire that began in Cambodia on 1 May? Is the cease-fire holding? What further progress does the Minister look to being achieved at the forthcoming Jakarta conference on Cambodia? When I asked the Minister here in the Senate on 7 March, a little over two months ago, about the prospects for the comprehensive settlement being achieved, he emphasised that the only substantive issue remaining was the demobilisation or disarmament arrangements. What does the Minister suggest will be the likely solution to this issue in the Jakarta conference? What is the present state of Australia's readiness to participate in any international peacekeeping force that may serve in Cambodia? Has the United Nations yet made any official or informal approach to the Australian Government about this country's involvement in peacekeeping activity in Cambodia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, the Cambodian parties have all accepted the appeal issued jointly by the United Nations Secretary-General and the Paris conference co-chairmen on 22 April for a temporary cease-fire or cessation of hostilities in Cambodia to operate from 1 May, at least until after the proposed meeting of the co-chairmen and members of the Cambodian Supreme National Council, which meeting is likely to take place in Jakarta between 2 and 4 June.

ANSWER.PARA: The Cambodian parties' acceptance of this appeal is an encouraging sign which everyone hopes augurs well for a productive meeting in Jakarta. The information available to the Government is that so far the cease-fire appears generally to be holding, although there have been some skirmishes since 1 May. Australia welcomed the further announcement that was made on 6 May by the United Nations Secretary-General and the Paris conference co-chairmen that they would send a military mission to Bangkok and Phnom Penh to review the situation first-hand. That mission, which comprises military representatives from France, Indonesia and the United Nations-that is, the two co-chairmen plus the United Nations, as well as a representative from the office of the United Nations Under-Secretary General, Rafiuddin Ahmed-is scheduled to visit zones controlled by the three resistance factions today and then to fly on to Phnom Penh tomorrow.

The Jakarta meeting, about which Senator Teague has asked me and to which I referred, will focus on major unresolved issues, in particular military arrangements, including demobilisation, and guarantees to prevent the return of genocide, which is a theme rather mixed up with the question of demobilisation. I do not want publicly to canvass the various possible ways of resolving this difficulty, except just to say that there are a number of formulae and approaches presently being considered. Australia has been an active participant in the diplomatic discussion about those possibilities. I think there is a chance of them being resolved, although it is probably unrealistic to expect them all to be resolved at a single meeting.

What we hope will happen in Jakarta is that it will at last clear the way for an early reconvening of the Paris conference coordination committee-that is, the Paris conference meeting at officials level. We expect that Paris conference to constitute the final negotiating phase of the peace process. That negotiating phase when complete will be followed by an implementation phase which will involve, among other things, a United Nations peacekeeping force. Again, it is premature to speculate publicly about the shape of any Australian contribution to that force. There have been informal discussions, as one would expect, with the United Nations Secretariat about that, but nothing that remotely clarifies what our specific commitment would be. It would be quite premature to go down that path at this stage.

In summary, it is Australia's judgment, and that of the vast majority of interested countries, that the United Nations peace plan for a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia still constitutes overwhelmingly the best available way of ending the conflict in that country and the suffering of the Cambodian people. Given the cumulative achievements of the past year, slow as they have been, and given the latest encouraging developments-and they are encouraging-relating to a cease-fire, it is our assessment that a comprehensive political settlement is now clearly within grasp. To give any confident prediction about the timetable or any confident prediction as to the actual outcome is difficult to do, given the inevitable uncertainties that continue to plague this process.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a question from Senator Hill on Thursday, 9 May, I said that Mr Brian Burke's resignation would involve a termination payment to him equivalent to 18 weeks and five days salary, calculated on the same pro rata basis as previously advised. I meant by that on the basis of a ministerial determination as to the appropriateness of such a payment, relying on the spirit of the existing compensation provision in clause 2 (A) (ii) of the terms and conditions of Mr Burke's appointment, but not the letter of that clause.

ANSWER.PARA: I have had the benefit of some further advice on this subject following my giving that answer on Thursday afternoon. It is necessary and appropriate to state for the record the exact position about the circumstances and implications of Mr Burke's termination.

The circumstances were these: it became apparent during the course of last Thursday when these matters were checked by my Department with the Attorney-General's Department that Mr Burke's resignation was not self-implementing. That applied both in respect of his original resignation of 29 April to take effect from 31 July, and also to the attempt to bring forward that date of resignation to last Thursday's date.

The advice was-and I guess this arguably should have been clearer earlier but the fact is it was only checked on this occasion-that to be effective it had to be accompanied by formal action by the Governor-General to terminate the appointment. That followed in turn from such appointments being, by their nature, at the pleasure of the Governor-General and, as such, not terminable unilaterally; only by the Governor-General's action.

This is the procedure followed every time there is a changeover of ambassadors in a particular post-whether the appointee is a career public servant or a political appointment; whether the appointment runs its full intended term or is cut short; or whether, if it is cut short, that is as a result of resignation or early recall.

It is a grotesque misuse of language to claim, as so many members of the media have subsequently, that Mr Burke was, as a result of this procedure, either sacked or dismissed. He was no more sacked or dismissed than Doug McClelland was on the termination of his appointment recently as High Commissioner to London or Sir Robert Cotton was, for that matter, on the termination of his appointment a few years ago as Ambassador to Washington. Exactly the same procedure was followed.

It may be that there was some misunderstanding of this point so far as the media were concerned, but I have to say that the Press Gallery was made fully aware last Thursday of the terms of the advice and the purely technical nature of the termination procedure in question, and, against that background, I can only describe a good deal of the reporting which has occurred subsequently as being quite shameless.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful! You are not one who could use that word.

—It is a badge of honour to be called disgraceful by Senator Walters. One consequence of a formal termination by the Governor-General being necessary to give effect to a resignation-which was not appreciated by anyone until the point occurred, it seems, to the Attorney-General's Department last Thursday-is that Mr Burke was in fact entitled, under the original terms and conditions of his appointment, to a termination payment equivalent roughly to one-third of his remaining salary for any early termination of his ambassadorship.

ANSWER.PARA: The point is, simply, that a termination is a termination is a termination. It is a neutral description of the process which occurs, whether that occurs as a result of resignation, dismissal or effluxion of time. Once one appreciates the procedures involved, the law is perfectly clear-and I should say there is no more credible foundation for Mr Peacock's fulminations on this subject in his press release over the weekend than there was for his earlier extravagantly wrong-headed allegations.

I am perfectly prepared to concede, as I have to, that there is an ironic quality to this particular revelation. Had the point been appreciated earlier, it certainly would have saved me, my Department and the Government an awful lot of trouble in the context of his first resignation on 29 April. But it is palpable nonsense to suggest that the Government is acting other than with absolute rectitude in the legal sense and every other sense in following the advice that has now been given to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill on 9 May 1991, relating to the termination of an appointment of the position of Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See.

Whilst, we were not, of course, given notice of that answer, it is inappropriate for me to speak in any detail at the moment. However, this is just another astonishing chapter in an astonishing saga. I understand that a further paragraph at least was written this morning when the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) organised the press for a doorstop to make it clear-probably on the instructions of Senator Richardson-that Mr Burke's employment was not in fact terminated, that he was not sacked, and that the Government had become distressed over the weekend to find it being reported that he was.

As of late last week the Government was acknowledging that that was the case. Therefore, the basis for the termination payment has varied-an irony or not, as the Minister says-as of last week when the Government accepted that Mr Burke's contract had been terminated, that is, dismissed by the Governor-General, and that Mr Burke was entitled to that money. This matter still has a long way to run because it seems clear, as it has seemed from the very beginning, that on a resignation the only basis for that payment the Minister decided to give to Mr Burke was purely as an ex gratia payment.

That, of course, would lead the Minister down a difficult path because he would then have been required to get the consent of the Department of Finance which, in fact, was not sought or given. Therefore, the Minister has to continue down this tortuous path of saying, as the Senate has just heard, that a termination is a termination is a termination. In other words, if people resign, they are terminated. Clearly, in any common usage of the language, that is not so.

The Minister used that language in the Estimates Committee. He tried to justify this payment as a termination payment. It is not a termination payment. If his employment had been terminated he would, under the contract, have been entitled, but the Minister cannot have it both ways. The Minister could have it both ways in the Estimates Committee and he cannot have it both ways today.

As I have said, I think this matter still has a long way to run. Ultimately, the legal advisers will be forced to the conclusion that what the Minister has done is to make an ex gratia payment. He has not made it in the proper form. I do not know whether there is a retrospective capacity to correct that error-if there is, the Minister ought to do that now because, ultimately, if he does not do so, he may well find that the Commonwealth is forced to seek that this sum of money be repaid by Mr Burke. I simply put on the record that what the Minister has contributed today does not in any way further clarify the matter, but just continues to confuse an already confused and sorry saga. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Regulations 5, 61, 63, 68, 71, 82, 85, 88 and 95 of the AUSTUDY Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 443 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

These regulations contain some of the most blatant inequities in the Government's Austudy scheme. We are particularly concerned about the 1990 Budget changes to the spouse income test; the continued discrepancy between Austudy and the unemployment benefit; the age of independence; and the personal income threshold.

My colleague Senator Lees will move to disallow the assets test regulations under division 2. The Australian Democrats believe that the family farm and small business assets should be exempt. Many young people are ineligible at the moment for Austudy because of their parents' occupation, although their parents may be earning little or no actual income.

As to the motion currently before the Senate, the Democrats challenge regulation 5 regarding the age limit on eligibility for Austudy. Regulation 5(a) provides that Austudy is paid only to students who are at least 16 years old. The rule is relaxed in regulation 5(b) for students who have reached the relevant school leaving age and are independent students who are orphaned, homeless, refugees or whose parents cannot exercise responsibilities. That is not in dispute.

The Democrats believe that the age limit on eligibility for Austudy should be changed from 16 years to 15 years or starting in year 11, as alternatives, because discrepancies exist between States as to which years students are in what level of study and what age they are typically at that level of study. As it stands at the moment, this age limit is purely arbitrary and it is a device to reduce costs. The effect is to discourage gifted students from progressing through school at a faster pace. Students turn 15 or 16 in different years, depending on the starting age in the States. Currently a 15-year-old student in year 11 or year 12 is ineligible, while a 16-year-old student in the same class may qualify for Austudy.

Under regulation 61, the Austudy living allowance is still lower than the unemployment benefit for people over 21, except in a few exceptional cases. This discrepancy and its associated disincentive to study must be finally removed for all categories of students. For adults aged 21 and over, the single rate of unemployment benefit at the moment is $268.60 a fortnight, which is $119.50 higher than the Austudy at-home rate of $149.10 and $42.10 higher than the Austudy independent rate of $226.50 per fortnight. For married people, the Austudy allowance of $226.50 a fortnight compares with the payment of $243.20 to each member of an unemployed couple. Also, it must be taken into account that students who are on Austudy do not receive rent subsidies and other so-called benefits which are available to people who are currently receiving the unemployment benefit.

The move to immediately raise Austudy to the level of unemployment benefit is supported by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, the National Union of Students and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I emphasise that the National Union of Students is a union. That union's log of claims is very similar to the alterations presently being sought by the Australian Democrats, and that is a point which needs to be stressed to the Government.

In its April 1991 Report on Student Financial Assistance, the House of Representatives Committee supports the change in eligibility for Austudy to make it available to students under 16. The Australian Democrats welcome this report. We recognise the many submissions and the many months of work that were involved in the preparation of that report.

With regard to regulation 63, with effect from 1 January 1991, the special rate benefit for people who have been unemployed for six out of the last nine months and who transfer over to Austudy will no longer apply to a married person with no children. This rule means that a recipient will go to a lower rate of benefit and be penalised for studying. That is because of the discrepancy between Austudy and the unemployment benefit.

This is where a complication, which is a trademark of Austudy, arises. It starts when an applicant for Austudy fills out the first form and has to address almost 100 questions. It continues throughout the regulations and the exceptions to the regulations to the point where, in regulation 63, there is an exception that if one received the special rate on this basis in 1990, it will continue. That is a transitional concession, which is probably admirable, but it just goes to show the sort of complication we have in this dog's breakfast of a set-up for students. Married students with children and sole parents do not lose payment under the new regulations. But if one is married and has no children, one is defined as a loser in this regard because one has lost some of the benefit one was previously entitled to.

Regulation 68 is another one we are attempting to disallow because, according to the age qualification in this regulation, students must be 25 years old to be classified as independent of their parents. The Democrats believe that the age of independence should be reduced from 25 to the normal legal age of adulthood; that is, 18 years. This is the only area where a person aged over 18 years and up to 25 years of age is still treated as a child and assumed to be dependent on parental support. Such an assumption is contrary to social security and other areas where 18 is the age at which a person is independent of his or her parents.

Honourable senators and everybody else in Australia are familiar with the age of independence which allows a person to become a voter, to hold a licence to drive a motor vehicle, to take out health insurance, to legally consume alcohol, to engage in debts, to be killed in warfare and goodness knows what other things which mark the reaching of majority. But as far as Austudy is concerned, a person under 25 is a child and it is assumed that he or she will be dependent upon parental support.

The House of Representatives Committee accepted the arguments which should derive from common sense and the arguments which challenge that ridiculous definition of independence. The Committee recommended that the age be reduced to 21. For budgetary reasons, the Committee recommended that this be achieved progressively. I have no argument with that at the moment; it is the principle which I fail to comprehend.

The National Union of Students believes that the age for independent status should be lowered to 18 years with an immediate reduction to 21 as a progressive step. The Democrats believe that it is only logical and fair that the age at which students are deemed to be independent should be reduced to 18 years of age. In support of that, I quote an example which came to our notice of a third-year engineering student. In a submission made in July-August 1990 by the University of Sydney Students Representative Council to the House of Representatives Standing Committee, the student is quoted as saying:

I was refused Austudy because of the level of my parents' income. The fact that I received no money from them, have not lived at home for 4 years and live in a different state was deemed irrelevant. The Austudy office has explained that as I had not been thrown out of home, or suffered abuse or generally horrible home circumstances, I was not eligible for homeless Austudy and could not be considered independent either.

There are many other cases which have come to light which show that many 18-year-olds are financially self-supporting, even if they do live in the family home. We acknowledge that the use of age and other criteria to determine independent status is arbitrary and unrealistic. It ignores the actual financial circumstances of students, many of whom can demonstrate independence outside the criteria that are being used. However, until we use a better method, the age limit should at least be lowered to the normal legal age of 18 years.

I turn now to regulation 71. According to the work force qualification under regulation 71, students must have been employed full time for three of the last four years to qualify for independent status. We believe that the work force qualification should be reduced to two out of the last three years. If nothing else, justification for that change could be based upon the present employment situation, where the sort of work which students or intending students may find available to them has been drastically reduced. I would have thought that such a change would need little if any other justification.

The return to the previous employment rule, as I have just described, is also supported by the House of Representatives Committee. In the present circumstances I would have thought also that some allowance could be made for part time work with a minimum number of hours per week to be decided. That again could establish the independent status of a great number of young Australians who have been independent but able to find only part time work.

I turn to regulation 82, under which the personal income test threshold is currently at $4,000 and includes income earned during the long vacation. We believe that this figure should be increased. It is entirely unrealistic as it stands. Depending on the new threshold, it should again exclude pay over the long vacation. That is a matter of particular concern to a student who may be able to arrange a regular and reliable source of employment over the long vacation only to find that if, under an award or in quite correct recognition of experience, an employer grants a pay rise in the second or third years of that regular employment, that student has effectively disqualified himself or herself from receipt of Austudy for the rest of the year, or at least finds it very difficult to make a case-or perhaps it has brought such a hiatus into that person's receipt of Austudy that the question arises as to whether the employment and receipt of money was any good. In fact, this situation has brought a great deal of inconvenience to a great number of students.

Part time work is increasingly difficult for students to find. Quite often, if it is offered, it should be accepted as immediately as possible, rather than being looked at and calculated with the student thinking, `Oh dear, I might go over my personal income threshold'. The quandary that some students find themselves in is whether to accept something that might take them over a threshold or to reject it and not find anything else for the next 18 months. That situation seems to have failed to be understood by those who administer these regulations or by those who designed them.

The House of Representatives Committee found that Austudy students who find part time work are amongst the most highly taxed sector in Australia. Students lose $1 of Austudy allowance for every $2 earned over $4,000 and the Committee found that when normal tax is taken into account, this represented an effective tax rate of 75 per cent.

The Committee Chairman, Labor member Mr Roger Price, said that the Austudy benefits and the personal income allowed fell well short of students' living costs, which evidence to that Committee suggests are about $12,000 per year. I would suggest that such an existence, for somebody who is attempting tertiary study, is at the very minimum of what we should expect our citizens to survive on. The Committee Chairman says:
It is illogical and unjust that the Government has set levels (of income) which do not enable students to meet their cost of living, particularly those students who receive no parental support.

The Committee recommended that the personal income threshold should be increased significantly. It suggests that allowable income should immediately be doubled to the level of $8,000 per year. Others have suggested that a personal income of around $10,000 would be more appropriate. This is not a gift that we are proposing for students; it is an encouragement for people to find part time work or regular vacation work which would allow them to accrue sufficient income to survive for the rest of the year.

We recognise that Austudy was never designed as something upon which people could rely entirely, but to be able to survive properly a personal income level of around $10,000 per year has been suggested by others. We believe that an increased level can and should be negotiated before this year's Budget.

We also support reinstatement of the incidentals allowance for Austudy students to contribute towards textbooks and course-based costs such as lab coats, equipment, stationery, et cetera. These are the sorts of expenses that a student usually has to meet at the beginning of the year and that reduces the opportunity to deal with other incidentals during the year.

Many tertiary institutions are finding any number of extra charges such as late application fees, particular course fees, photocopying fees, tutorial payments, payments for notes that are photocopied and produced for tutorial purposes. These fees, which I would question, are becoming commonplace in our tertiary institutions. They are all significant. We are not talking about 20c and 40c here and there; we are talking about hundreds of dollars in some cases that are applied by some tertiary institutions, it seems willy-nilly, as a revenue raising exercise. I may have more to say about that at another time, but this is the sort of thing which applies directly to many of those students who are having financial difficulty and are troubled by the Austudy regulations we now have.

The methods that some of our students have to undertake to avoid the financial hardships that are caused by these regulations have been chronicled in a number of places and I refer to some of them now. According to reports in the Adelaide Advertiser and the Melbourne Sun on 6 September 1990, some tertiary students may be marrying and then separating to obtain Austudy benefits at favourable rates. This means that testing for Austudy was independent of their parents' income and that assets of their parents were not taken into account either, and it could have entitled them to greater benefits. Some of those sorts of contrivances are being encouraged by the regulations that we have before us.

Other news from South Australia is that students are turning to prostitution in order to survive tough economic times and inadequate Austudy. That news is not limited to the South Australian press. Yesterday, 12 May, the Sunday Age carried an article which suggested that students turn to sex to make ends meet. There are other reports of such terrible circumstances in other parts of our media.

There have even been claims by a spokesperson for the Prostitutes Association of South Australia, Mr Brett McMillan, who claimed that up to one-third of the State's 600 prostitutes were tertiary students. Reports in the Flinders University student newspaper, the Empire Times, on 21 March 1991 and in the Adelaide News on 11 April quote Mr McMillan as saying:

Prostitution is about dollars. In the education system there have been increasing fees and more stringent tests for Austudy. Because prostitution is quick money and they can work nights, it's an alternative.

I move away from that horrible state of affairs and turn to a matter which is perhaps less disturbing but similarly, involves a regulation which should be challenged-regulation 85. Under Budget changes, a step-parent who is normally in the same house has his or her income and assets taken into account in assessing a stepchild for Austudy. It might seem logical to assume that the step-parent contributes directly or indirectly to the study and living expenses of a stepchild. However, it is inappropriate to infer an imposition of that sort and, therefore, to impose an obligation as a result.

I am reminded in passing that such assumptions are made often by this Government and I am surprised that it does not deem that such obligations are met. It seems to be fashionable at the moment for this Government to deem that all sorts of things take place. When a step-parent does not normally have any legal or financial obligation towards the stepchild, this is an illogical and unfair assumption to make.

Until last year's Budget, if a student provided a declaration certifying that the step-parent did not contribute to his or her upkeep, eligibility was assessed on the income of the biological parent. But now the actuality is ignored-no matter what the actual financial arrangements are, the step-parent's income is to be included as part of parental income.

The Democrats believe that where a student can prove, by statutory declaration, that his or her step-parent does not contribute financially to his or her upkeep, the step-parent's income should not be considered for purposes of the parental income test. Surely that is a logical position to take. This Government is becoming increasingly capable of ignoring reality. I challenge the Liberal-National Party coalition to recognise that such ignorance should not be supported.

In regulation 88, the parental income test of $19,300 per year is far too severe. That income level is well below the average Australian income and it must be increased. I am quoting the House of Representatives Committee quite often here because I agree with a great deal of what it found. I would note in passing that there were no Democrats on that Committee because it was a House of Representatives committee and I am pleasantly surprised by the sensible recommendations which that Committee made, independent of our advice.

I am surprised here that in following its advice we received such a consolidated block of potential opposition from the major parties, because members of this Committee came up with recommendations with which we agree to a large extent. One of its recommendations was that the parental income threshold should be 75 per cent of the average male's annual wage, or $21,000 in 1990. It recommends that students from families with an income less than 75 per cent of that amount should receive full benefits. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee argues that the threshold should be 100 per cent of average weekly earnings, and the National Union of Students recognises that it should be at least that amount. So the present amount is certainly under question.

I turn briefly to regulation 95. The spouse income test threshold has been massively reduced by $6,000, from $18,150 to $12,150 per year. That is untenable. It is totally ridiculous to make that move in these regulations. That is a fundamental reason for our objection to this regulation. The Government has already backtracked on its lowering of the threshold under the parental assets test which it reduced to $200,000 a year and later restored and indexed to over $340,000. As we have argued-and I am sure Senator Lees will argue more strongly as well-this should now exclude farm and small business assets.

In the interim the Government should rethink these changes to the spouse income test. It is an incredibly harsh measure and it further excludes women in particular. It is particularly harsh on young couples, forcing them further into poverty. The spouse income test is a major barrier to participation of women in tertiary studies, particularly mature-aged women who want to enter the labour market through further education. As soon as the spouse income test is applied, effectively most people in that situation are excluded.

This further restriction strongly discriminates against married women whose partners earn a higher part time income than their female counterparts, and many women have been forced to drop out of courses and others have been barred from entry because of it. It is my contention that this move demonstrates the Government's lack of real concern about the equity and access of people wanting to engage in tertiary studies. The Government should at least restore the spouse income test to the pre-Budget level. I can find no justification whatsoever for the proposal.

This motion to disallow these regulations and to reform Austudy is supported by the National Union of Students. Several student unions, student counsellors at tertiary and secondary levels, welfare groups, individual students and their families, farmer organisations and a number of other people who are directly and indirectly affected support this action. To suggest that the regulations should be passed because they are in plain English and, therefore, more easily understood, is to ignore the central effect of these things-that is, that they will bring new, harsh economic conditions upon those people in whom we trust to bring about our very future and they will insult these people by saying, `We want you to bring about a future for us', and then refuse to give them the economic wherewithal to do so.
