TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the Austudy scheme of student allowances for those in full time secondary and tertiary study is governed by the Student Assistance Act 1973. That Act is of small compass and, to make it work, it is required that there be regulations as defined in this Act. The regulations are very considerable, so for the past 17 years the Austudy scheme, or the tertiary education assistance scheme-TEAS-as it was formerly known, has been governed by the Act together with the regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: In the event of policy decisions made at the last Budget in August 1990, it was determined that the amending of the regulations to implement those policy changes ought to be accompanied with a comprehensive review of the regulations to put them into plain English, because they are one of the pieces of Commonwealth legislation that is most referred to by users-by students, staff, families, persons contemplating a course of secondary or tertiary study and so on.

They have already been much used for 17 years and, in fact, amended mostly every year, and there is a large volume of paper to show for it. I happen to have been asked by the former Minister, Kim Beazley, Sr, back in 1973 to be on the advisory committee for the first drafting of the original regulations under the Student Assistance Act. I was very proud to have served in that first formulation of these regulations. This was some five years before I was elected to the Senate.

Of course, there have been many good developments all to the same purpose that we had in mind in 1973, which was to make the later years of secondary and all tertiary study in Australia the more accessible to Australians of all ages; that is, by making sure that those in financial need were not denied the opportunity of following up their abilities and interests by enrolling in higher education and tertiary study generally.

I say that by way of introduction to put in context that the Opposition has a bipartisan approach with the Government. The Opposition has just as often called for plain English versions of often-used law. This is a very good example of an outcome in which the regulations much used by the Australian public are now in plain English form. They are comprehensively put together and are, I believe, much more useable. It is a very welcome development that we have called for, which has been achieved.

That is not to say that the Opposition has confidence in the present Austudy scheme, the Act or these regulations. We went to the last election promising a complete review of Austudy. That means that in government we will completely review the Act and these regulations to ensure that the original objectives are being achieved. I will refer to many of the disabilities and inequities in the present Austudy arrangement before us.

However, let it be quite plain from the start that we have before us two disallowance motions with regard to some of these regulations. Honourable senators can take the opportunity, with their being before us now, to put their spanner in the works and to try to get policy changes foisted upon the Government. The only way they can do that is by disallowing particular regulations. I will go to the merits of those attempts by Senator Lees, in the first case, and Senator Bell, in the other, to show that the Opposition is not convinced that these attempts to put a spanner in the spokes will lead to an overall improved situation in the regulations.

What is needed is a comprehensive review of the kind which we can only fully implement in government. However, the Opposition is calling for immediate action by the Government-and we hope, given the eloquent words of Senator Bell along similar lines, that the Australian Democrats will support this call by the Opposition-to make sure that there are provisions to help, particularly, farming families presently in terrible circumstances because of the rural crisis. I will come back to that later on.

I begin by referring to Senator Lees's motion which she moved and spoke to on Thursday, 9 May 1991. That disallowance motion of Senator Lees which is before the Senate today seeks to disallow Austudy regulations 13 to 20 completely, thus removing the assets test from the Austudy regulations. It is important to understand that we are not being asked to disallow some of the assets test regulations, or to reduce the impact of the assets test on particular targeted classes of students such as rural students. The Senate is not able to amend the regulations in any way. This debate is about a black and white choice either to disallow all the regulations 13 to 20 that impose the assets test, or to allow them all to stand.

I stress this point because much of what the Australian Democrats have been saying in the Senate and around the country has been to object to the impact that the Austudy assets test has on some students, particularly those from rural areas. However, what Senator Lees's motion would do is assist far more outside this targeted area of rural areas. This disallowance motion would benefit all students from families with assets exceeding $750,000, not counting the family home. That will cost more than $50m. That would mean that families with assets of more than $750,000, in addition to the family home-which would usually mean that the families would have at least $1m worth of assets, I put it to the Senate-would all be helped by the motion that Senator Lees has in front of us today; not just the families that everyone in the Opposition is concerned about, which are those suffering from the rural crisis.

As I say, it will benefit all students. I do not believe, and the Opposition does not believe, that the Senate would be justified in taking such a broad-brush approach to this issue. In fact, the general case for retaining an assets test on Austudy alongside the present income test is a matter of fairness and equity. The Opposition reiterates its call for a thorough review and overhaul of Austudy which we will do when in government. In this review, the Opposition would accept the general case for an assets test on Austudy. For this reason, and for a series of specific reasons which I will go on to outline, the Opposition will not support this disallowance motion.

There certainly are problems with Austudy and its assets test. One problem is the immediate need for rural families to be assisted by the introduction of hardship provisions for Austudy as stated in the Opposition policy. However, we are not now debating legislation which the Senate can amend. We cannot, here in the Senate, replace these regulations with an amended or alternative policy. Therefore, I will indicate to the Senate the main elements in the Opposition's policy on this matter, a policy which we urge the Government immediately to adopt. I ask Senator Bolkus and his advisers to note that we will be proposing direct, immediate action by the Government to implement hardship provisions especially to help those families suffering in the rural crisis.

If the Labor Government lacks the political will to do this-to introduce hardship provisions to immediately assist rural families-I indicate now, on behalf of the Opposition, that we will introduce reforms as set out in the Opposition policy when we come to government. I will now move, on behalf of the Opposition, an amendment to Senator Lees's motion. I move:

Omit all words after ``that'', substitute: ``the Senate calls on the Government to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from AUSTUDY by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds''.
In support of that amendment, I refer to this morning's Australian and quote the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). Today's Australian at page 5 says:

Mr Kerin said yesterday that Cabinet confirmed on April 17, when funding to the Rural Adjustment Scheme was increased by $100 million to $164 million, that farmers were eligible for hardship provisions under the Social Security Act.
Mr Kerin said many farmers would not be aware of the range of facilities available through Section 7 of the Act.
``Farmers who meet the other normal eligibility conditions may qualify for support under hardship provisions and may receive unemployment, sickness, or special benefits and pensions'', he said.
Assets tests do not come under consideration in hardship provisions if the property cannot reasonably be expected to be sold or used as security for borrowings.
If payments are granted, the value of assets which cannot be sold or borrowed against will not be counted under the assets test.
I repeat that last statement. These are the Minister's words:
. . . the value of assets which cannot be sold or borrowed against will not be counted under the assets test. The benefit paid to the farmer then depends on a special income test.
There is discussion in the report as to what that income test is. The income test is considerably less onerous than is the case.

The Opposition's amendment in respect of educational allowances calls on the Government to immediately implement a parallel set of hardship provisions. We are quite specific as to the exact form of words of those hardship provisions. The Opposition does not have the facilities of government to have the precise knowledge of all the existing hardship provisions in other legislation or know the best way to frame this against the present Austudy regulations, but we are very confident that the Government has the competence to implement the amendment that I have now put before the Senate.
I remind the Senate of the Opposition's policy at the last election. Our higher education policy included the following statement:

As budgetary circumstances permit, a Liberal/National Government will work to improve the support given to needy students through Austudy and Abstudy. Particular regard will also be given to the needs of regional and rural students who have to travel long distances, or be accommodated away from home, to attend higher education institutions. We will establish a realistic assets test including a hardship provision.
I continue to quote from the policy of the Opposition:

Austudy has been bedevilled by administrative deficiencies and suffers from continuing allegations of unfairness in the award of benefits. The Liberal and National Parties will, in government, thoroughly review the rules and administration of Austudy to ensure that they are fair to all and that the scheme runs smoothly.

That will be a great improvement to Austudy, but it is not enough. We can put that into practice when we are in government, but we are calling upon the Government directly to act. With Democrat support, the policy determined by the Senate today will be that there be immediate action on the introduction of hardship provisions to assist rural families.

Similar words appear in our schools policy, which also refers to our approach to the assistance for isolated children scheme, where, in contrast to Austudy and for distinctive reasons that distinguish the common needs of all isolated families, our undertaking is to abolish the assets test for the AIC scheme, it would remain. In government, we will remove the assets test on the isolated children scheme. I also remind the Senate that the Opposition has already successfully acted on its policy to resist the Government's attempt to implement an assets test on family allowances.

On the general question of principle of an assets test on Austudy, it is the Opposition's long held view that Austudy benefits should be targeted to those in greatest need. We do not believe that the country can afford to have them available to all. Even the extension of Senator Bell's motion-which I will come to in a moment-will cost more than $1 billion. Senator Lees's motion will cost more than $50m, but Senator Bell's motion will cost $1 billion. An actual estimate was given to me of $1.2 billion, but I have given Senator Bell the benefit of the doubt by only quoting $1 billion. I ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), when he comes to sum up, to say whether the estimate of the cost involved in the extra Austudy is $1 billion or the $1.2 billion that Senator Bell's motion would entail. What extra taxes would the Democrats impose to gain that kind of money?

We believe that Austudy should be not a universal living allowance but targeted at those in greatest financial need. At the moment, only 40 per cent of students receive Austudy. The targeting of Austudy benefits to those in greatest financial need has been the firm foundation not only of Austudy but of TEAS in the previous 17 years and of the Commonwealth scholarship scheme before that, right back to when Menzies introduced it in the middle 1950s. I ask the Democrats whether they intend to abandon that basic foundation of the Commonwealth scholarship scheme, the TEAS scheme and the Austudy scheme. If so, I ask them to tell us where the money is coming from. What extra taxes will be placed on Australians, including farmers and rural families, to pay for the amount involved in Senator Bell's motion?

However, we point out that there are real problems with the way in which the assets test is operating at present. Hence I turn to the need for the hardship provision that our amendment calls for. We in the Opposition have been directly critical of the way in which the Government is administering the Austudy scheme. We are also critical of government administration of the assets test, especially the evaluation procedures which, in rural areas, have been notoriously inept, onerous and unfair. It is no wonder that we are getting hundreds of calls in our offices about the inept, unfair and onerous administration of the evaluation procedures.

I have drawn a distinction between the assistance to isolated children (AIC) scheme and the Austudy scheme with regard to assets testing. Austudy's whole rationale is to provide financial support for students who might otherwise not be able to support themselves adequately during their studies. It is a financially targeted concept. It follows that it is logical that some form of assets test be part of the eligibility requirements for Austudy. On the other hand, the AIC, the isolated children scheme, is best seen as a form of compensation by the community for the additional costs involved in obtaining access to education for students from isolated areas; that is, the AIC scheme is for all students from isolated areas. An assets test does not logically fit with the concept of the AIC scheme. The Opposition is opposed to an assets test on that scheme; we have said so in our policy. I reiterate that it is our policy now and we will take it to the coming election.

Things are very wrong with aspects of the present Austudy scheme and its present assets test. The Opposition is critical directly of the Government, as I have said. There is genuine concern and alarm in the rural community about its fairness and administrative efficiency.

With the present crisis and the fortunes of Australia's primary production sector, farm families are being unfairly hit by the assets test. It is possible for families with low or even negative incomes to be excluded from receiving Austudy because the book value of farms remains relatively high. The Government has constructed this assets test on the assumption that assets can readily be converted to cash. But that is not the case. In fact, this is an entirely inappropriate assumption for the Government to make about our rural areas at the present time.

As opposition senators would say again and again, a farmer cannot sell half his station to get some cash to pay a current need like a child's allowance. To be viable, a farmer has to keep the station or keep the eventual base for an income by having a viable sized farm in any area of primary production.

There have been particular problems in my own State of South Australia. This is parallel to other parts of the country. Tasmania, Queensland and Western Australia have real problems such as those in South Australia. I urge the Government to approach demands for repayment with great sensitivity when an upward revaluation of a property indicates that Austudy should not have been paid to a particular student and money is then demanded by the Government to be repaid.

Even when repayments have to be made, I have learned of numerous instances where students or their families have thought that a large sum of money had to be repaid immediately rather than, as is the case, repaying by way of reasonable instalments which are negotiated with representatives of the Austudy scheme. There have been those-they are not from the Opposition-who, for their own political purposes, have gone around the country playing on the anxiety that has resulted from all of this. Let it be made clear, however, that there are procedures for reviewing such situations to which families can appeal. When a review is applied for, the demands for repayment are then frozen until the matter is determined.

The Democrats have had a lot to say in rural areas about these issues, but not all of it has been balanced, and they have sometimes heightened the distress already felt by rural families by playing on anxieties. I wish to commend the statements made not only by Neil Andrew, the honourable member for Wakefield, but also by Senator Olsen, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and, indeed, other Liberal senators and members in my State who have not increased the anxiety but who have acted in a practical way to direct families to the appeal mechanisms and have indicated what their rights are, what the procedures are and what they should expect.

In my own case, I have received an enormous number of distress signals from the Eyre Peninsula, the Mallee and many other rural areas. At the weekend Dr Michelmore of Karoonda telephoned me to say that his patients throughout the whole region of the middle Mallee in South Australia are showing physical symptoms of acute distress. We are very aware that this is the time for planting and the time when judgments have to be made on outlaying extra capital in order to see a return. We need to see this Government respond immediately to the Opposition's call as set out in the amendment.

I now refer to the problem of valuations. My time is limited, so I have cut down my speech. The valuations of the Australian Valuation Office are often higher than valuations made by local or State government or private sector valuers. They can lag behind shifts in the local real estate market. Of course, in the last 18 months there has been an enormous decline in the actual value of rural properties. The Australian Valuation Office is behind the times. In answering this problem, I ask the Government to make sure, not just through the appeals mechanism, but administratively, that the valuation procedure is up to date and is not inflated.

I also refer to the sudden death nature of the cut-off point; there is no tapering provision in the assets test. The straight deduction for debt does not make any allowance for the proportion of debt on a property and the administration of the system of appeals is sometimes felt, by those affected in these ways, to be insensitive and demeaning.

I draw the attention of the Senate to a recent report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment Education and Training. I welcome this comprehensive report in which some of my colleagues participated very usefully. I do not have time to include in my speech further consideration of that report, although I have several pages of comments that I would have liked to refer to.

Disallowing these regulations today would not help to move Austudy policy or administration in the direction that the Opposition is advocating. Only a change of government will achieve that, and only the Government's response to our amendment will ensure the immediate response that we regard as important. The Democrats motion, therefore, does not warrant the Senate's support. The Democrats want to use this occasion to parade as friends of the farming community, but what hypocrisy this is. The Democrats advocate a whole series of policies that are in fact damaging to the rural sector. I will list some of them. The Democrats support Labor's capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make them up.
—Make them up as you go along.

—They are parroting on now, but they will not deny this: they support Labor's capital gains tax and they want to abolish the live sheep trade. They support a Federal land tax. They want death duties on properties which are worth more than $300,000 and they want to reduce, and eventually ban, intensive animal production. The Democrats are no friends of the farming community. They are using the Austudy issue to try to cover up their anti-farmer policies. To do so is in fact a political fraud-and I have not referred to the increase in taxes that the Democrats want to place on rural communities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not support this disallowance motion. The motion does not, and cannot, offer a means of carrying out the changes to Austudy policy and administration that the Opposition advocates. The improvements and reforms to which we are committed will occur when we are in office and are able to implement them, and when the Government responds directly to our amendment.

I have only a few minutes in which to refer to Senator Bell's motion. I will speak briefly and indicate that the Opposition cannot support this motion because it would make the Austudy scheme inoperable as of today. For a start, it would disallow regulation No. 61 which sets the rates of allowance. By abolishing that section alone we would have no Austudy scheme as of today.

It appears from Senator Bell's speech and from the attitude of the Democrats generally that they do not understand the effect of the passage of his motion. I do not really believe that this unintended consequence of gutting Austudy is the deliberate objective of Senator Bell and the Democrats. Surely it is an unintended consequence, but it is a consequence and it is factual. Will the Minister refer directly to this? I ask the Minister: will there be an Austudy scheme if Senator Bell's motion for disallowance is in fact adopted today?

I make it clear that we do not support the abolition of regulations 61, 63, 82, 88 and so on. I have already referred to the cost, which will be at least $1 billion. Not one Democrat senator has referred to where this $1 billion or $1.2 billion in additional spending would come from if their objectives, as stated, were to be achieved, that is, to make Austudy available to not only those in financial need but also even the affluent students, those who are not in the targeted group of those in greatest financial need.

We have then the ludicrous position whereby the whole Austudy scheme would be rendered useless if Senator Bell's motion were to be passed today by the Senate. I therefore regard this approach, with such dire unintended consequences, as slapdash and irresponsible. I am afraid that this type of approach has become typical of that adopted by the Democrats when they want to grandstand, in a populist way, in order to appeal to particular groups in the electorate. In the case of Senator Lees, it is rural areas and, in the case of Senator Bell, it is the National Union of Students and students generally, not just those in financial need.

When the Democrats want to grandstand and gain some sort of support from particular groups such as these, they know that because their attempt in the Senate is irresponsible it will be thrown out by the Government and the Opposition, and they can then go about and say, `We tried to help you, even though it was in an irresponsible way and a way which would not be effective and we didn't tell them about the cost'. Therefore, the Democrats are able to say that they have been frustrated by the Government and the Opposition in gaining the goodies.

I regard that kind of wish-list, irresponsible approach by the Democrats as being all too typical of its appeal to be popular with particular sectional groups in the community. I reject that approach and the Opposition rejects this disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —In coming before the chamber today, the Australian Democrats advance the argument that what they are doing is designed to advantage family farms and people with small businesses. However, I believe that the motions put forward by both Senator Lees and Senator Bell disclose another agenda, a secret agenda, in the educational debate-that is, to make Austudy available, not just to those people who need Austudy, but to every single person who happens to be at university.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of Senator Lees's motion, which is a motion for disallowance of regulations which relate to the assets test, is to effectively strike out, lock, stock and barrel, the assets test, not just on the family farms and small businesses from one end of this country to the other, to which she refers so frequently, but on absolutely everything. But this is not what Senator Lees has told the people to whom she is trying to sell her policy. At this point, I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a media release issued in the name of Senator Lees, dated 7 February 1991, entitled `Democrats launch Austudy access plan for country students' and the attached notice of motion.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DEMOCRATS LAUNCH AUSTUDY ACCESS PLAN FOR COUNTRY STUDENTS
South Australian Democrat Senator Meg Lees today launched her party's ``Austudy Access'' plan for country students at Booleroo Centre in the State's mid-North.

The three point plan is aimed at making education allowances more available to country students by relaxing the assets and income tests applied to parents' incomes and by varying the eligibility criteria.

Recent figures have shown that Australian farmers in general have very little formal education when compared with their OECD competitors. It is estimated that 75% of farmers did not get to the senior years of high school.

While these figures reflect the ageing of farmers as a group, and younger farmers are better educated in comparison, the Australian Democrats believe there are obstacles put in the way of farming families when they seek education for their children.

Launching the plan Senator Lees said: ``The Australian Democrats believe that country children are being disadvantaged in their access to upper secondary and tertiary education. One of the most important reasons for this disadvantage is limited access to Austudy and other education allowances.
``This package is designed to redress access inequalities. Its points will be transformed into federal parliamentary initiatives during 1991.

``The Democrats believe that for Australia to become the `clever country' access to education allowances is vital. Austudy and Assistance for Isolated Children must be viewed as investments in this country's future. The costs will come if these initiatives are ignored.''

Senator Lees said that the new generation of farmers would continue to be Australia's economic backbone well into the next century. She stressed that for Australia to retain its comparative advantage in agriculture those young farmers must have far greater access to educational opportunities.
Details of the Democrats ``Austudy Access'' plan follow this statement.
NOTICE OF MOTION
That the Senate-
1. registers its serious concern at the plight of farming families throughout Australia as their incomes continue to decline rapidly;

2. notes that the Australian Valuation Office continually values farm properties well above the valuation commonly agreed to by Local Councils, Rural Land agents and State Government Valuers for the purposes of assessing the assets of rural people for Family Allowance Supplement, AUSTUDY and other pension and benefit payments;
3. notes that as a direct consequence of the discrepancies between AVO and other genuine valuations:
- many young people, whose parents own farms, are not able to continue their education,
- many rural families are having their assets retrospectively assessed and are being forced to repay AUSTUDY payments,
- other families will remain ineligible for Family Allowance Supplement despite having low or negative incomes,

- many rural women who are separated from their husbands will be ineligible for any assistance from the Department of Social Security, despite them being unable to realise their assets to the amount of the valuation provided by the Australian Valuation Office and their incomes falling well within the relevant income tests;

4. calls on the Government to move to redress this situation by ensuring that the Australian Valuation Office's valuations reflect local market reality and acknowledge that the family farm is a ``tool of trade'' and not a readily realisable asset; and

5. calls on the Government to recognise the hardship presently being experienced in rural Australia by exempting the value of the family farm from the assets test for AUSTUDY, Family Allowance Supplement and other pensions and benefits.
Signed:
SENATOR MEG LEES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I take the opportunity to highlight what is said in this press release so that people can really understand what Senator Lees is trying to do. Senator Lees has been telling everybody, from people in Isolated Childrens Parents Association branches-and I got this material from an ICPA branch in Queensland-to producer organisations and anybody who would be silly enough to listen to her speaking from the back of a truck, that there is a three-point plan aimed at making education allowances more available to country students by `relaxing the assets and income tests applied to parents' incomes and by varying the eligibility criteria'.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, what we have in the motions from Senator Lees and Senator Bell is completely different from that. They are not going to relax the assets test because, by the time Senator Lees is finished with what she is doing, there will not be an assets test. We are not varying by any small degree the eligibility criteria, because Senator Bell's motion effectively hands Austudy to any people who happen to have their hand out at the time.

If Senator Bell's motion did not make the scheme inoperable, it certainly would make the scheme totally unfeasible. The real agenda behind the Democrats and what they are doing in the chamber today is certainly not designed to advantage the school students in particular who come from country areas. Instead, their plan is designed to hand out more welfare and more assistance to their suburban supporters in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Canberra. Senator Teague has stated so well today that the real cost just of Senator Lees's motion would be $60m, most of which would end up in the cities-not in the country where it is needed, not assisting school students--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty-seven.

—I thank the Minister. His estimate is $57m, which is close enough to ours to show that what we are talking about is indeed accurate and our assessment of the situation is much more realistic than the assessment of the Democrats. I will return to the cost of the Democrat agenda in a few minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: Not all the cost will be related to assistance to students in country areas. Instead, most of the assistance coming forward will be aimed at people who live in the cities-not the people that Senator Lees is trying to convince that she is helping; indeed, quite the opposite. She is trying to advantage her suburban supporters in the cities; nothing less.

If Senator Lees really stood by her access plan for country students, she would be supporting Senator Teague's amendment, which I shall be supporting this afternoon. If Senator Lees were really concerned about assisting people in country areas who are affected by this government-inspired rural depression, she would be targeting her assistance at those people in country areas. Instead, she comes before the Senate and says, `We are going to throw out the assets tests, lock, stock and barrel'.

I asked members of the ICPA and people in country areas, ranging from Cape Tribulation, Charters Towers and Emerald to other areas in provincial Queensland, what they thought of the idea of making the assets test a non-entity, of throwing it out and giving Austudy money to everybody who comes along, irrespective of their circumstances. Overwhelmingly, they said that they could not support throwing out the assets test. They said that in this time of financial stringency it is necessary to be careful how we spend the dollars. Their concern is to ensure that the assistance that we do give-and we must give assistance-is targeted to the people who are really in need. Yet Senator Lees--

TALK.START.PARA: —We have an income test. That is why we have got it.

—I thank Senator Bell for his interjection. I hasten to add that the interjection came from a man who wants to abolish the income test. It shows the absurd, ridiculous attitude of the Democrats. It shows how their policy is totally inconsistent with the sorts of things they do when they come into the Senate chamber. I only wish that the people of provincial Australia knew of the sorts of things that the Democrats were doing and knew of their policy hypocrisy. I flatter them by calling it `policy hypocrisy'; it is just hypocrisy, or whatever happens to suit them at the time, that they perpetrate in the Senate and then try to peddle to people throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: For those reasons, there is no way in which I, as a responsible member of this Senate, as a person who is truly interested in country students-and not just university students; all students-can support this motion. Even if this motion were passed today-and I do not believe that it will be-the funny thing is that it would make the Democrats' Austudy access plan for country students totally superfluous and of no effect at all. The Democrat policy, as enunciated in the access plan for country students, talks about changing valuation criteria; but there is no point in changing valuation criteria if there is no longer anything to value.

Maybe Senator Lees is an acrobat, because the policy backflip that is effected by the motion she brings before the Senate today is quite extraordinary. She parades herself around country South Australia by putting out a press release. She sends it to people living as far away as Cape Tribulation and goodness knows where in Western Australia. She puts forward this policy, saying, `This is the brave new world; this is the Democrat vision of how we are going to improve access and equity for country students', and then she moves a motion in the Senate that will disallow regulations and have the effect of making her policy a nonsense. I suppose the argument that it makes her policy a nonsense is a bit flattering anyway, because those of us who look at it in the cold, hard light of day recognise the fact that the Democrat policy is and always has been a nonsense, that the things that Senator Lees is doing here today are indeed a nonsense.

But what is worse is that, by saying one thing and doing another, Senator Lees has taken advantage of people who are vulnerable, who are upset and who are looking for any life raft onto which they can possibly grasp. She is really playing upon using those people who are in vulnerable circumstances. I, for one, am particularly disturbed that a member of the Senate can tell people that the Democrats are doing one thing and then come in here and do another. For that reason, I have no intention of supporting the sort of nonsense motion that Senator Lees has bought into this chamber, a nonsense motion that will make nonsense of a nonsense Democrat policy.

Now we come to the issue of whether we should be trying to target Austudy, or whether other things need to be done that should have a greater priority. On Friday members of the National Party met with the Federal executive of the ICPA. We asked those people in our meeting whether they thought it was worth while backing the Lees motion with its intention to abolish the assets test for Austudy. The answer was very interesting. It was an unequivocal no. They said that Austudy is not a priority so far as the ICPA is concerned, because Austudy is intended to assist principally, though not entirely, students at tertiary institutions. But my concern is for the people who in the current rural recession will not get to a tertiary institution because they will not finish high school or because, although they might finish high school, they will not have access to the sort of education that will get them the tertiary entrance score to enable them to get into a tertiary institution.

Let us look at the assistance for isolated children (AIC). As I said, the ICPA was unequivocal in its opposition to abolishing the assets test on Austudy while at the same time maintaining an assets test on AIC. This would be the effect of the Democrat motion. In other words, if one happens to have a child who is in primary school, in grade 8, 9 or 10, or even a grade 11 and 12 student who is not eligible for Austudy, that is too bad-the assets test will remain. It is too bad that the student cannot get to school, too bad that the student cannot get a proper high school education. But at least the trendy intellectual who lives in a city and votes Democrat and who has enormous amounts of assets, the Democrats say, will be allowed to get a tertiary education.

I am very concerned for the primary and high school age children who will not get a proper education under this Democrat motion. That is why we in the coalition support what the ICPA is doing, and why we have as part of our policy a firm and thorough commitment to abolishing the assets test on assistance for isolated children. Why should we abolish the assets test for assistance for isolated children and not do so in respect of Austudy? The answer is simple. It is that there is a substantial difference in intent between the assets test for assistance for isolated children and that for Austudy. Indeed, there is a fundamental difference between AIC and Austudy. Assistance for isolated children is intended to even out the inequities of distance that strike parents and students who live in remote areas.

The ICPA said, I believe correctly, that AIC should be approximately 55 per cent of boarding costs at high school. The reason is that that would be roughly the difference in cost between living at home and boarding at a school. For many people in far-flung areas in my State, and I know for many people in far-flung areas such as Western Australia-and I recognise that Senator Knowles and Senator Crane have come to this chamber with very real concerns for these people-it is the tyranny of distance and the inequities which that distance impose on students that will defeat many of them. It will prevent many of them from getting to high school and from studying the subjects in which they want to achieve.

If there is a limited public purse available, then as far as I am concerned our first and foremost obligation must be to give these students a chance to get to university rather than assisting the people who are already at university, who tend on the whole to come from the cities. Senator Lees herself has identified the fact that a disproportionate number of university students are from country areas, and the question is: why? The answer is that the AIC has been allowed to slip away, has been shackled by an assets test, and now no longer achieves its stated intention, which is to equalise the disadvantage suffered by people in remote and rural areas.

I hasten to add that in 1973 there were 30,000 AIC recipients; by 1989 there were 13,000 AIC recipients; and by 1990 there were 9,000 AIC recipients. The coalition's policy would increase the number of recipients for assistance for isolated children's allowance and would allow more of these children-primary school children, children in years 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12-a chance of a decent education at high school or primary school just like their city cousins.

One of the things that strikes me as absurd about an assets test for AIC is that one of the assets of a professional person who lives in a city is a degree. It is the diploma people put on the wall; whether it is a law degree, a medical degree, a teaching diploma or whatever, it is an asset. That assists in keeping one's family, yet that asset is wholly untested by this existing policy on AIC. Yet if one happens to work with one's hands or works on the land, or is a truck driver or a baker, or any person who has not had the advantage of a university education, all one's assets are tested and taken into consideration. It strikes me that it is a grave inequity that favours city intellectuals rather than the people who live in the country who work with their hands and who suffer most in this current Government-engineered recession. I think that is wholeheartedly absurd and offensive to the principle that every Australian is equal and deserves equal consideration.

The Democrats are not really assisting the children from isolated areas; they are assisting the adults and the perpetual students. They are assisting their own supporters in the cities rather than doing what they say they are doing, which is assisting the isolated children. I understand wholeheartedly what is going on in country Australia. I understand the horror that is being experienced.

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll support you. Move an amendment.

—Senator Bell interjects by saying that if we move an amendment he will support it. I remind him that Senator Teague has moved an amendment. It will be very interesting to see whether Senator Bell will support it. It will be interesting to see him putting his feet where his mouth is. I understand that Senator Bell does that quite frequently, but this time I want him to walk across the chamber and vote with us on our amendment. Interestingly enough, our amendment will give more effect to the Democrats' access for country students policies than would the motion that is now brought before the chamber by Senator Lees. If the Democrats really believe in their policies, they will support the amendment moved by Senator Teague. If the Democrats do not believe in their policies, they will show the craven nature of the things they have been doing to vulnerable people in country Australia by voting against it, by blocking it, by moving to support not the people who are affected in country areas but their own intellectual supporters in the cities who have their degrees, who are not assets-tested on those degrees and instead are looking to disadvantage the people who live in country areas. That is why I find Senator Lees's proposal so absurd.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on briefly to Senator Bell. It is only fitting that I be brief in dealing with his motion because it will not take long to dispose of. Senator Teague suggested in the debate earlier this afternoon that the cost of Senator Bell's motion would be in the vicinity of $1 billion. He would be doing away with the income test, the test that five minutes ago Senator Bell interjected in my speech was worth keeping. The Democrats would be doing away with the spouse test and with all the other eligibility criteria referred to in Senator Lees's policy. Maybe there is a policy difference between Senator Bell and Senator Lees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paid for by wealth taxes and capital gains taxes on homes.

—Exactly. The policies would be paid for by wealth taxes and capital gains taxes on homes. I thank my colleague for that perspicacious observation. We have to bring out in public the shameful carrying on of the people who sit on my left, and `sitting on my left' is indeed an accurate description of the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now turn to the matter of the $1 billion cost that Senator Teague has identified in his speech today. The most eloquent, the most perceptive and the most cutting argument that Senator Bell could come up with by way of interjection was, `It's your estimate of cost, not ours'. However, what we have not heard from the Democrats this afternoon is their estimate of the cost. As far as the Democrats are concerned, cost is irrelevant. It is irrelevant to their pie-in-the-sky plans; it is irrelevant to the promises that they make in the electorate; and it is irrelevant to their wish list, which in this case includes the abolition of the income test, put by Senator Bell just minutes before he said to me that it was necessary to preserve the income test as a safeguard.

Indeed, if I were to liken the proposals put by Senator Lees and Senator Bell, taken together, to anything at all, I would liken them to a sort of creeping, subversive, Fabian socialism-the type of attitude that says that we will give money to people left, right and centre, we will make people everywhere dependent on government handouts, instead of giving them the opportunity to get on with their lives for themselves.

How will we pay for these sorts of things? Where will we find the $1 billion? The answer is that the $1 billion will come not from income taxes, not from taxes on people's ability to pay but, according to the Democrats' proposal, from an inheritance tax. An inheritance tax is just a death duty by another name. What is the point of encouraging university students from country areas to go to university when, if their parents die, they will not be able to keep the family farm and will have to sell it to meet the Democrats' inheritance tax? This is the truth behind the Democrats' policy. It is the truth behind the way these people attempt to fund their as yet uncosted wish list.

TALK.START.PARA: —Politics of envy.

—It is the politics of envy-thank you very much, Senator Knowles. The real cost is probably even more than the $1 billion that Senator Teague has identified. It is probably much worse than the $57m under Senator Lees's proposal. The real cost is the heartbreak and the hurt that these Democrat policies will cause people in the bush. At a time of bereavement, when a person's spouse or mother or father who has a share in the family farm dies, the Democrats will send people around to assess the farm. They will ask that person for a share of the value of that farm, ask him or her to cough it up, otherwise he or she will not be able to inherit it. That is what a death duty is; that is what a Democrat inheritance tax is. It is sending an assessor around to assess a person's farm just days after his or her parents or spouse has died, and asking that person to cough up a cheque to pay for a share of the value of a farm that has been in the family for generations. I find that iniquitous and offensive, particularly at a time when people are suffering a bereavement. That is the real truth about how the Democrats would run this country. For those reasons, and taking it in a complete context, I do not believe that anyone who is reasonable or anyone who has any real concern for people in country areas could support this Democrat proposal. I certainly will not do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all those people who were listening to the National Party's Senator O'Chee will have sensed more than a touch of panic in his speech, because in an hour or so from now he will have to either support or reject these regulations. He has made his speech and he will now have to support or reject regulations which impact upon his constituents.
—It's my constituency, not yours.

—I have been into the constituency-which is mine as much as yours, Senator O'Chee-on other issues and, while I have been visiting, people have raised this issue with me. At this stage there is no need for me to tell any senator or, indeed, any Australian of the depth and dimensions of the rural crisis. It is a rural crisis the likes of which we have not seen previously in our lifetime. That has been confirmed in my mind by visits to the Eyre Peninsula, and, as recently as 48 or 72 hours ago, to Albury and Shepparton. Also, I will be in Dubbo on Saturday. SPEECH.PARA: We are, of course, debating a motion to disallow two sets of regulations. Those who are listening to this debate may need to be reminded that the regulations cannot be amended. So, in reality, there is no substance, impact or effect to come from the amendment that Senator Teague has moved.
