In a few minutes from now National Party senators will do nothing about the regulations, but with much flurry they will support an amendment of no consequence whatsoever. This is the essence of the debate: utterances of no consequence. The only thing of consequence that can happen here today is the disallowance of these regulations. We have heard a lot of hot air.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are hearing a bit more now.

—The hot air that we heard from Senator O'Chee a few minutes ago was born of the panic that will be in his guts in an hour from now when he has to do something of consequence. I have been into the rural communities, talking mainly on the issue of banking. In the context of deregulated banking, I believe that a great deal of the blame for the rural crisis that we are seeing now can be sheeted home to greedy banking. Rural Australia is now confronted with the plague of indebtedness. That in itself is bad enough. It is an indebtedness, as I have argued over and over again, that is substantially born of deregulated banking-but not totally. Even when confronted with that plague of indebtedness, farmers are still hopeful for the future of their children. They are still hopeful that they will have access to the great Australian entitlement of equality of opportunity, including educational opportunity. Today we have an opportunity here to disallow regulations which are reinforcing massive inequality in relation to access to education.

SPEECH.PARA: We see the situation in rural Australia where, due to greedy banking and this rampant plague of indebtedness, many farmers have been reduced to little more than peasant farmers. Some decades ago they were called serfs. We remember that in 1917 there was a revolution, which has been so derided, in order to throw over a set of circumstances in another country that were not really unlike those that many people in rural Australia find themselves in today. It is little more than serfdom, little more than peasant farming, toiling probably for the rest of their lives to service debt that was imposed upon them by irresponsible bank practice and inappropriate Government policy in introducing deregulated banking.

When I was on the Eyre Peninsula, a farmer, who I do not believe would cry very often, came to me following a public meeting and told me about the circumstances in which he finds himself. In 1980, he borrowed $120,000 from his bank and since then he has paid the bank $290,000 in repayments and he still owes the bank $185,000. He will never pay that debt in his lifetime, and nor will his children, if they retain the property and keep working it. That is little more than serfdom or peasant farming. One could cite hundreds and hundreds, if not thousands and thousands, of farmers across this nation in similar circumstances.

This Government, supported by this Opposition-the deregulators gone crazy-has imposed upon rural Australia the deregulation not only of banking but also of the primary sector at large, and the deregulation of almost everything that allowed the rural sector to support this country so proudly for so many decades. This is what I am being told by the farmers in my constituency, which is mine as much as it is Senator O'Chee's.

We see before us today two sets of regulations which, if endorsed by this chamber-and they surely will be in an hour or so from now-will compound that situation. However, we can change that set of circumstances in an hour from now by not supporting the amendment moved by Senator Teague but supporting the motions for disallowance that have been moved by my colleagues Senator Lees and, from Tasmania, Senator Bell.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Austudy scheme would then collapse, as of today.

—That is not so. I shall leave it to Senator Lees and Senator Bell to respond to the quite invalid arguments that have been advanced by Senator Teague and Senator O'Chee. The simple reality is that in a few minutes from now National Party senators will not deliver to their constituents. Their constituents know that will happen. Indeed, they have approached me in the last few days while I have been in Albury and Shepparton, and two weeks ago when I was on the Eyre Peninsula, with their fears-the disillusionment of non-representation. When it comes to the harsh realities, it comes to where one sits in this chamber and what one votes for, not the rhetoric which has been flowing from their elected representatives for decades.

SPEECH.PARA: As partners in coalition, National Party senators do not have the opportunity to put up legislation that will determine the circumstances of people in rural Australia; that is coming from the Government. National Party senators frequently support legislation which has created a set of circumstances confronting rural Australia. Today, in an hour from now, National Party senators will have the numbers to scuttle the regulations that put in place the formulas that judge these rural Australians to be asset rich when they are well and truly income poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —How often do you support them?

—Senator Panizza and I both know that these people are not assets rich. It is the formula which judges them to be so. That is the reality. Many of these people have less than a five per cent equity in the assets which are still, by deed, theoretically theirs. In reality, the assets belong to the banks. The banks are the real controllers and owners of the assets. It so happens that, by inappropriate, unjust and distorted formulas, these people are judged to be rich.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was at Tumby Bay the week before last I listened during a public meeting to rural councillors, representatives of the United Farmers and Stockowners of SA Inc. and farmers. They said over and over again that the equity in their properties had fallen to almost nothing. They put in front of me worked examples of figures to prove that the equity in their properties, which had been 80 per cent five years before and 60 per cent three years before, in some cases, is now five per cent or 10 per cent. Yet they are judged to be rich by virtue of the fact that the deeds of those properties happen to be written in their names, even though they have been mortgaged well and truly-and possibly several times over-to enable them to stay on the land and stay in place.

As I said in a notice of motion in this place upon my return from the Eyre Peninsula, it became crystal clear to me that thousands of rural Australians are moving inexorably into bankruptcy. Their debts have to be restructured by legislation so that they are not forced off their properties. The fact is that the people in this plight are not assets rich and they certainly are not income rich. Some have zero income.

When visiting women's crisis centres at Port Lincoln on the Eyre Peninsula I heard those who administer these crisis centres emphasise the fact that not only is the financial crisis real but also it has now become social, emotional and psychological in its dimensions. The number of women and children seeking refuge from the distress and the agony which Senator Teague cited-he accused us of having compounded it or having created it in some spurious unjust argument which he advanced-is real. It is compounded by these regulations. It is compounded by bureaucrats who ruthlessly apply formulas which arrive at totally inhuman and invalid answers.

I cite some examples of the outcomes of those formulas. The Isolated Children's Parents Association, to which Senator O'Chee referred repeatedly, in a document prepared by its federal council entitled Access to Education-which is the whole reason for its existence-cited a series of studies, some of which apply to the deprived circumstances in which schoolchildren of rural families find themselves. A number cite quite specifically the circumstances in which tertiary students of rural families find themselves. I cite just two of about eight cases annexed to the document.

A case study taken from mid-northern South Australia involves three children in a family undertaking tertiary education: the first is completing an honours degree, the second is in third year university and the third is in the fourth year of university studies. The family has been asked to repay the 1989 and 1990 Austudy amounting to $16,063. Austudy was advanced to and accepted by this family in good faith-frankly, we would argue, and the Opposition would argue, grossly deserved. The family is now being asked to refund $16,000-worth of money which was advanced to it in good faith in accordance with the set of formulas which then applied.

The family's assets have been reassessed. The Valuer-General's capital valuations of the property of $516,000 in 1989 and $578,000 in 1990 were used. The Valuer-General's valuations have now been officially reduced by $21,000, due to mistakes in the valuation. However, the Department of Employment, Education and Training did not accept the Valuer-General's figures and the Australian Valuation Office revalued the properties at $735,000, which is almost a 50 per cent increase in the valuation. After review, the figure was reduced to $675,000.

What is in this process of valuation? It is valuing properties which farmers do not own in any real sense. They are in hock to the bank for up to 90 per cent of this valuation figure, yet the bureaucrats play around. There were three sets of figures from three different sources, one of which admits mistakes in the valuation. The whole exercise is irrelevant anyway. The effect of it is to ask the family to give back $16,000-worth of Austudy. Surely, the concept of giving back social service benefits is ludicrous. People with zero income are being asked to give back money that two years ago was advanced to them for the education of their children, based upon a range of valuations which were admitted by the valuers to contain mistakes and upon two valuations which differ in the order of 50 per cent.

I turn to a second case study, which is once again from mid-north South Australia, where there are two children undergoing tertiary studies. On the advice of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the farm assets were valued as per council rates notice less the replacement insurance value of the house plus curtilage. That does not mean much to me but that was the formula which was applied. The Commonwealth Valuation Office revalued the property over the limit and all payments had to be repaid within 14 days. They were not advised at the time that they could appeal. Senator Teague has talked about stress and he has blamed us for being responsible for this level of stress.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, added to the stress.

—Okay, we have added to it, but the realities are that we have added nothing to it and Senator Teague knows that to be a fact. We have been in these rural areas trying to assist these people in the process of coming to grips with policies that have resulted from the Opposition supporting a government which initiated the legislation. It was put into effect with the Opposition's support, not ours. Time and time again the Opposition sits with the Government to allow the Government to put into effect this sort of legislation. In an hour from now, the Opposition will be confronted with the opportunity to diseffect it but it will not do that. Senator Teague has moved a spurious amendment which the Opposition knows has no effect upon the circumstances of the people who are impacted upon by the regulations which we are attempting to disallow. In the final analysis, when all the rhetoric is over and done with, it is only by disallowing these regulations that we can begin to redress the extraordinary injustices.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party will be called to task on how it votes today. I have no doubt about that at all. The National Party knows it and that has given rise to the gross distortions that it has introduced into this debate and to which my colleagues will respond, because they have the right of reply.

Essentially, it is about equality of opportunity but it is specifically about equality of educational opportunity. By attempting to disallow here, we are addressing the instruments of disequality, namely, regulations. We have no choice. We cannot change the regulations. We can either accept them or reject them. If we reject them we send them back whence they came, to their authors, who can change them. When the authors come forward with a set of regulations which put in place formulas which project justice, then they will find that the Democrats will support them.

We disallowed pharmaceutical regulations in this place some months ago and the world has not come to an end. The disallowance of regulations does not bring the world to an end. It sends signals to the Government to bring to an end the gross injustices which in this case deprive rural Australians who are desperate because many of them have no income at all. Most of that I personally would place at the door of greedy banking. Most of these rural Australians now cannot even look forward to passing on to their children the same opportunity to work the land that they themselves have done so effectively for decades.

What we have before us is an opportunity to do something in support of those people, that is, to redress inequalities of access to education. We therefore call upon at least the National Party senators with conscience to cross the floor today and display the moral courage, which is the only way to reinforce and put substance into the rhetoric that we have heard from the likes of Senator O'Chee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak on this motion for disallowance of Austudy regulations, I would like to begin by reading out the amendment, which my colleague Senator Teague has put before us:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate calls on the Government to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from Austudy by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.
Alongside that, I would like to quote from today's Australian the following statement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin):
Assets tests do not come under consideration in hardship provisions if the property cannot reasonably be expected to be sold or used as security for borrowings.

I do that deliberately because there must be consistency across the board in policies and positions. I want to deal with the motion by saying that, in terms of asset testing, I support very strongly the fact that when money is being handed out of the Government purse it should be asset tested. Also, there must be flexibility in how that is done and difficult circumstances must be allowed for. In what Minister Kerin had to say in terms of the asset tests in a different arena, he is allowing flexibility.

What we on this side of the chamber today are putting to the Government is that it should apply that same flexibility in terms of Austudy. In addressing this issue and this debate, I must comment on some of the things that have been said here today, particularly by the Australian Democrats. Unfortunately, once again, the Democrats are being very opportunistic because one must recognise that, when one moves to take away the assets tests or adopt their line, additional finance is required and that has to be collected from somewhere. My colleagues have outlined in their comments on policy positions a number of areas in which this would happen. What I am saying is that, if a free feed is to be given on the one hand, there has to be some mechanism for financing it on the other hand.

The very people whom this motion is designed to help, at the bottom line, will be those who are made to suffer the most. This debate is really about rural Australia and those people who are caught up in the rural crisis now. They are price takers because they cannot pass their costs on. Ultimately, additional charges are passed right down the line. That is the distinction between the position that we are adopting and the position that the Democrats are adopting.

I am rather disappointed that Senator McLean left the chamber so quickly after speaking, because I found his comments in regard to Senator O'Chee, when he talked about hot air, rather remarkable. We have to listen to Senator McLean on a whole range of issues night after night, speech after speech, when the smoke is coming out of his nostrils and the steam is coming out of his ears, yet he gets up and accuses one of my colleagues of speaking hot air.

Let us look at some of the facts surrounding this debate. The recent Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics survey results indicate that about 50 per cent of farms have net assets worth in excess of $695,000. They also indicate that somewhere between 40 per cent and 50 per cent of those who do not have the required level of net assets are receiving Austudy. The problem we have is that there is too much variability with an assets test applying to farmland. Senator Teague referred to that and I will expand on it.

There is considerable volatility in valuations. Australia has valuation procedures. There is a commercial valuation and a stress valuation. I know what Minister Kerin meant when he used the term `cannot reasonably be expected to be sold or used as security for borrowings'. It is important to understand just what stress valuation means and how it works in terms of commercial valuation. When a bank assesses what an individual can borrow, it generally takes 50 per cent of the stress value as the benchmark. In reasonable times, or good times, the stress value is normally considered to be two-thirds of the commercial value. In tough times such as we have now, it can drop to 40 or 50 per cent of commercial value, which means that the capacity to borrow against that asset is reduced very significantly.

I want to cite some figures at this time to emphasise how important it is for the Government to show consistency in its policy, just as we are showing consistency in our position. The Government is showing consistency when it says that government assistance should be subject to an assets test. For the sake of easy sums, I will round off the $695,000 which is allowed now to $700,000. In good times, the stress value would be $462,000 and the farmer or the small country business can borrow up to $231,000 against it. In bad times such as we have now, the stress value reduces from $462,000 to $350,000 or less, which means-taking 50 per cent against that-that someone can borrow only up to $175,000.

So in terms of what are relatively short term requirements for education, the capacity to borrow against that asset is reduced significantly. In addition, irrespective of whether we are in good, bad or other times, it is impossible to sell the back paddock or the front paddock and it is impossible for the small business in the town to sell off one of the rooms of its garages, one of its showrooms or parts of the yard. That is not a practical proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still can't get Austudy.

—I will come to that in a minute. We are addressing a way of overcoming the problem, not carrying on with a lot of hot air-to quote somebody in this chamber today-or trying to score political points in the country by putting forward erroneous arguments. We are trying to work out a method by which the problem can be addressed, which we can put to the Government. On top of that, the levels of borrowings that might apply against a property or business at a particular time impact very differently. If a person has an asset valued at around $695,000, with no debt, that person is in a very different position from a person having an asset worth, say, $1m with $400,000 or $500,000 debt against it. We cannot have these things fixed so hard that there is no flexibility left. That is what we are talking about today. This is what our argument is about. We are asking the Government to be consistent by allowing the same flexibility with Austudy as it has allowed in other areas. That would be the mechanism by which we could address this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that aspect of the issue because we are not talking about something out in the field, or in the country, which is rigid. Yet we have a set of rules in front of us which are absolutely rigid and which do not allow a practical way of overcoming the problem. At the bottom line, I am sure all of us in this chamber would want the very people we are talking about-that is, students-to have the opportunity of equal access to education. In this debate we are dealing with a group that is disadvantaged by geography or the tyranny of distance. That has been mentioned already today. That tyranny of distance varies from student to student or from position to position. That is why we say that it is important to introduce a mechanism which allows flexibility in dealing with the problem.

Looking at the overall contribution from recurrent expenditure on higher education, it is worth noting that currently the contribution rate is running at about 19 per cent. If we compare that figure with those of other countries, we find that in France the rate is 9.2 per cent; in Italy it is 2.9 per cent; in Japan it is 0.5 per cent; in the Netherlands it is 10.1 per cent; in the United States of America it is 8.4 per cent; and in the United Kingdom it is 20.3 per cent. The figure for Australia is sitting at 19.3 per cent and only one country actually has a higher rate. When we compare the contribution rate for Australian students with the contribution rate of other countries, we find that we are up there with the best.

Returning to what I said earlier, I emphasise that we are looking to introduce a mechanism which will allow flexibility in stressful times, when valuations have an enormous impact on the capacity of an operation, a property or a business to borrow or sell, and where there is genuine hardship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make several points, particularly about matters which have been raised by members of the Opposition. In debates such as this it is important to remind the chamber exactly what we are dealing with. We are dealing with regulations which substantially modify the Austudy provisions in that they reduce the amounts which are available by altering various aspects of the means test and requirements which have to be fulfilled before one qualifies for Austudy. The regulations substantially increase the inequity in relation to applicability of Austudy because of those changes.

SPEECH.PARA: As several of my colleagues have pointed out, in dealing with regulations we do not have the option under the procedures in this place to amend regulations. We must either accept those regulations or disallow them. The motion before us, moved by my Australian Democrats colleague Senator Bell, is to disallow certain of those regulations. Senator Bell has set out the particular regulations and the reasons why those regulations are repugnant to the Democrats. The other part of the process that we are going through this afternoon is one which we have gone through very often in this place, in that we have seen speaker after speaker from the Opposition telling us how inequitable a particular set of regulations or a certain piece of legislation is. Then, having waxed lyrical, having become angry, having had, to use Senator Crane's words, fire emerging from the nostrils and steam from the ears, the Opposition then turns around and votes with the Government and supports the piece of legislation or the regulations in question.

That, of course, is precisely what we have this afternoon. We have heard many cogent reasons from the Opposition as to why these regulations should be disallowed and why the Government should be forced to go back and look at them again, to come up with different regulations. We have had specific examples of the way in which particular aspects of these regulations impact adversely on sections of the community, especially the rural community. However, I would point out that, while that section of the community is one which has been particularly adversely affected at this time, our primary concern in disallowing these regulations is the general principle of inequity. It just happens that at this time the rural community is particularly hard hit and, therefore, the aspect of inequity is adversely affecting it more than perhaps many others. But the inequity also relates to many people in the urban community. It is the inequity and the lack of adequate provision for help which is affecting us.

The Opposition, having given good examples of the impact which these regulations will have on many disadvantaged people, will nonetheless at the end of the day vote with the Government for the passage of these regulations. Is it that Opposition members now have their eye on the next election and are quite happy to keep in place some disastrously iniquitous regulations because it will advantage them when the next election comes along? They will be able to turn to the speeches they have made this afternoon and quite dishonestly say `Look, this is what we said at the time'. They will ignore the fact that they voted for these regulations and the impact of those regulations on the general public at that time will, they hope, advantage them in electoral terms.

I venture to suggest that the procedure we are seeing this afternoon is as dishonest as that. They are prepared to impose regulations which, by their own words, they recognise as bad, harsh and inequitable. They are prepared to impose those regulations on the community simply to gain an electoral advantage when the next election comes along.

This afternoon we have heard from the Opposition several quite incompatible assertions. We heard from Senator Teague that the Democrats were supporting a change in regulations which would impose further financial constraints on the Government. `Where is the money coming from?', he asked rhetorically, and gave no answer. That was a constant theme throughout the speech. Yet, when Senator O'Chee spoke, he was full of all sorts of places where he thought the Democrats or the Government would get money.

TALK.START.PARA: —He made them up.

—As Senator Bell reminds me, he made them up on the way. That is precisely what Opposition members do when they want to launch into the Democrat-bashing that we heard this afternoon. Death duties was one of the things that were hoarily trotted out. Death duties is not-and I repeat not-part of Democrat policy. It is absolutely dishonest of Opposition members to claim either in this place or outside, as they have, that death duties are part of our policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Tax on the family home was trotted out. That is not part of the Democrats' policy. I ask Opposition members to look at our printed policies and see precisely what those policies are and not simply go scaremongering-and I use that term advisedly because that was the accusation made of us-among their constituency, suggesting that the Democrats' policy is something which it is not. We are quite happy to stand by our policy, and we set out in our alternative Budget last year precisely not only where the amount of money would come from to meet the Government's proposed excess but also a great deal more than that, and we set that out in great detail. So to claim things other than that is simply quite dishonest of the Opposition.

I return to the process that we are going through this afternoon. I said earlier that the mechanisms allowable in this place are simply the passage or the disallowance of regulations. In fairly recent times we have had an example of the way in which disallowance of regulations works to the reasonably rapid advantage of the passage of very much improved regulations. I refer here to the passage of the therapeutic goods regulations. Not unlike the Austudy legislation, as Senator Teague pointed out, that is a simple enabling piece of legislation and the guts of the action, as it were, comes out of the detail, which is found in regulations .

The Therapeutic Goods Act was essentially the same-a very simple Act, and the guts of the action which was to be taken under that Act is to be found in the regulations. When those regulations first came before the Senate, the Democrats moved for their disallowance. In other words, that Act could not operate until those regulations were in place. That was supported by the Opposition. We then went into an extensive period of consultation and negotiation with the Government which eventually, after six or seven months, saw the passage of regulations which were substantially different from the regulations which were first put before the Senate, with substantial improvement to the operation of those regulations and indeed with almost unanimous support from those in the community who were concerned about those regulations in the first instance. That is the sort of thing that we would hope for in relation to these regulations.

There are indeed existing regulations in place. The regulations now before us are to replace certain of those regulations. The regulations now before us, as Senator Bell has gone through in considerable detail, both decrease the availability of Austudy and make it less equitable in its application. I recap several of the regulations which Senator Bell ran through. In South Australia-and I should imagine the situation is somewhat similar in other States-we have in the Elder Conservatorium of Music in Adelaide an institution which has always taken gifted students at much earlier ages than the age at which students would normally matriculate, because music is one of those gifts in which very often children at a very young age are able to advance much more quickly than the average. We have seen students far below the age of matriculation attending the Conservatorium and doing advanced studies.

Mathematics is another area where peculiarly gifted children are able to advance at a very rapid rate. We have recently seen the case of a student engaged in mathematics to the level of graduating from university at the age of 14. The adherence to a particular age-the age of 16-as Senator Bell has pointed out, very severely discriminates against those gifted children who may come from disadvantaged families. Children coming from well-off families-families which can afford to allow them to advance if they are gifted-will succeed, but this country is probably missing out on the talents of a great number of students who, through no fault of their own, simply have come from families which do not have the wherewithal to allow them to advance at the rate at which they may otherwise do.

Senator Bell also went through the various criteria in relation to the size of incomes; the students; and the students' supporting parents, quasi supporting parents, step-parents if they happen to have them, and their spouses, if they happen to be married. In every instance, these regulations make the provision of help to students more difficult and less equitable.

On frequent occasions we have heard from the lips of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the term `clever country'. My response to that term, when I first heard it and certainly as I hear it now from the Prime Minister, is that we need cleverness in this country not in the area of the ordinary community but in the Parliament of this nation. What we need far more than cleverness is wisdom. One needs look no further than these regulations to see the lack of wisdom exhibited by this Government. It is not wise to cut off at source those students who wish desperately to go on with tertiary education, but who are made incapable of progressing through that education simply because this Government progressively decreases the support to those students. It is not particularly wise; it is certainly not particularly clever.

I am desperately worried that 15 to 20 years down the track, if we continue to pursue the course that we have in recent years, not only will we be a banana republic but also we will be in desperate straits. There will not be the educated talent around to make this the interesting, vital and creative country that it should be. It is for those general reasons that I find these particular regulations quite repugnant. Therefore, I believe that they should be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have seen this afternoon is very much a battle of popularism-one that appeals very much to the electorate but, I think, reflects a fair degree of fiscal irresponsibility. The degree of financial anarchy which has been shown by my good friend Senator Bell this afternoon in the way he has approached this matter is one which we ought to take into account when we are assessing the debate that has gone on this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone listening to the debate would have thought that the Government has ignored students and that care and sensitivity are on the other side of the Parliament, only-whether it is the Australian Democrats, the Liberal Party of Australia or the National Party of Australia.

There has been a competition going on to see who can best represent the views of the electorate but, when one looks at that, the basic position from which to start is the record. When one looks at the record in terms of assistance to families with students in education, one sees a totally different picture emerging. It is very easy to come in here, as the Democrats have this afternoon, and give us a shopping bill of $1.2 billion by way of amendments to the regulations. It is very easy to make all sorts of comments supporting mechanisms and allowances here, there and everywhere. One really has to start with the record and the sorts of cutbacks, or areas, that one would look at in terms of priorities, if one were to adopt some of the proposals put forward.

As I have mentioned, family payments under this Government have been indexed in such a way that maintains their real value and costs revenue $1.5 billion a year. It is not a small piece of the cake, it is a substantial amount, and I think it is one of the great achievements of this Government. Those payments go very much to the heart of assisting families in the sorts of situations that have been mentioned this afternoon.

Let us look directly at student assistance and the most immediate record; let us look at some of the indicators; let us look at some of the most recent history; and by doing that, let us reflect on the sorts of comments that have been made this afternoon. In terms of the number of students who get assistance from government, in 1983-under whatever schemes were in operation at the time-just over 150,000 students received government assistance to go through education. In 1990-the last year for which we have figures-that figure had increased to 353,000. In 1983 it was 30 per cent of the student population, in 1990 it was 40 per cent. There has been a 33 per cent increase in the number of students receiving assistance under this Government.

That assistance has not been given without an allocation of further funds. Over the last financial year, for instance, funds under Austudy have increased from $823m to $965m-double the rate of the inflation increase over that period. When one also looks at the number of students receiving assistance from government over that period, there is an increase from 319,000 to 353,000. Once again, that is a substantial increase over a period of 12 months. Achievements have been made and there have been increases in expenditure in all these areas. In recognising the achievements and placing them on the record, it is important to note that the Government still ploughs on with policy development in this particular area.

Another indicator is the retention rates. Whereas in 1987, when Austudy was introduced, 53 per cent of the student population stayed through the education process, in 1990-once again, the latest figures that we have available-that figure went up to 64 per cent. That is an important increase over that short period of time.

Regarding the sorts of people who are getting assistance to go through education, the most disadvantaged 20 per cent of the population is that which is doing year 12. Over the period 1986-1989 there was a 5 per cent increase each year of those from that part of the population who received government assistance and stayed on through the schooling process.

It is very easy to come in here and do what has been done this afternoon, but one really needs to take an overall perspective of this area, and recognise that this is probably the only government that has actually tackled this area in an honest way. One should also recognise that it has only been in recent months that we have realised that Austudy needs to be reviewed, and a review is going on. That is pretty well known to the Senate and it is pretty well known to the student population.

I say to honourable senators opposite that it is pretty irresponsible to come in here and come up with a billion dollar package-as has been done by the Democrats-present that to the student population and raise expectations that these sorts of spending levels can be achieved. The student population understands that they cannot: the Australian Democrats are dealing with a population which has a few clues and can see through them. I do not think the Democrats are doing themselves or the community any service by raising false expectations in the community.

I turn to Senator Bell's points. His disallowance motion would preclude the payment of Austudy to any student. The reality is that the previous regulations have been withdrawn and rescinded; that was done earlier this year. If the regulations that are the subject of the debate today do not go through, no regulations will apply. Moreover, if some of the changes that Senator Bell proposes were to go through, we would have enormous costing to revenue. I said $1.2 billion; in a few seconds I will go back to explain how that figure is actually arrived at.

In terms of Senator Lees's proposals on the assets tests, her colleague has done her a disservice. She probably ran on this issue for a while in South Australia and in other areas. The whole area has really been generalised so much that the focus of what she is on about has been missed in this debate, not only in terms of the points that she wants to make but also in terms of the points that the Government would want to make.

For instance, those interested in the plight of farmers-and the farmers have had a fair mention this afternoon-should realise that they already have an assets cut-off which is double the normal assets cut-off point; it is $695,000 instead of $347,500. The Government has already relinquished the 1990 Budget decision to reduce the assets cut-off point to $200,000 and $400,000 for farmers. The Opposition should realise that we are responding in that area in a way that is a cost to revenue. It should also realise that we do not have the $1.2 billion to go around.
There is a shaking of the odd head by some on the Opposition benches in terms of the $1.2 billion. But let me look at a couple of areas of Senator Bell's--

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, that was the estimate the Opposition made.

—Before Senator Teague came in here I made the point that there has been a bit of political point-scoring this afternoon due to this populism that seems to emanate on broadcast day. The figure that I have is $1.2 billion. I do not know whether it is one that Senator Teague has developed, but I am assured that it is one that comes from the Department of Employment, Education and Training rather than one that has been developed in any political office. That is an assurance I have just had confirmed.

SPEECH.PARA: If, for instance, one looks at the amendment to regulation 68-the independent age provision-one finds that the proposal is to abolish parental income tests for students aged 18 and over. As we know, it currently applies to students aged 25 and over. I am advised that the cost of that proposal would be $700m. That in itself is halfway towards the $1.2 billion that I mentioned earlier. Obviously, we realise that we cannot amend regulations, but a pure disallowance of this regulation would remove the concession for students aged 25 and over, and that would just throw the whole scheme into disarray.

In terms of another big ticket item, I turn to regulation 88-the threshold for parental income tests. As we know, the proposal is one that really cannot be pursued because the Senate does not have the power to amend regulations at this stage. The proposal is to increase the threshold of the parental income test with no new level proposed. The cost of raising the threshold to average earnings, as Senator Bell appears to propose, is $300m. I am advised, not by a political office but by the Department, that those two items would mean $1 billion expenditure. As I said, that is Senator Bell's proposal.

Senator Lees targets the assets test. One needs to take into account the Government's position, which it has stressed quite clearly. One actually has to ask oneself: in an area where it is contended by the Democrats that money can be found, what would actually happen if the funding in this particular area were targeted by removal of the income test? What would happen is that those who are most in need would have to share this part of the cake with those who are less in need. That would really do a great disservice to those in the community who are most in need when going through schooling and education.

Senator Lees has to take into account that, as I said earlier, we do have special provision for farmers in small business. The effect on farmers is reduced by the 50 per cent discounting for family businesses. There is also the isolated secondary students allowance for those students over 16 who need to live away from home. In those cases an allowance of $1,500 a year is payable free from the income assets test under the assistance for isolated children scheme. In addition, we should recognise that rural families also benefit from the country areas program, increased funding for school student hostels and improved access to higher education provided by assistance education centres.

There is also a mechanism in the scheme as it now operates to take into account the assets at the time of payment. Parents can ask to be reassessed if the market value of their assets falls during the year. Anyone who has taken an interest in this scheme understands that. That provides a very useful mechanism in times when prices are falling. When looking at assets in this area, one should also take into account that we are looking at the net market value of assets. We are excluding the value of the family home and the value of debts on those assets. As I said earlier, it applies to only 50 per cent of the value of assets if a person works a family business. For instance, with the 50 per cent discount, the amount is $695,000 for parents with combined assets. It is a fairly big amount. Having said that, I would be the last to state that there are no problems in the scheme. As I say, the Government has already picked up that issue and is conducting a review to that extent.

The sorts of proposals that we have had this afternoon are populist. They are very unfair and they are misleading to the client community. When addressing this debate honourable senators should recognise that enormous inroads have already been made. I mentioned them earlier in terms of retention rates, moneys spent and concessions that the Government has made in relation to, for instance, the assets test. But one really cannot come in here with proposals that would cost $1.2 billion, that have not been worked out in their detail, that really should go before a continuing review and that raise false expectations in a community, particularly amongst those who, in some respects, are quite desperate to have those expectations raised. Those people are led on in a way that they should not be. The Government opposes the disallowance motions moved by the Democrats and does not support the amendment moved by Senator Teague.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to support the motion that has been moved by Senator Teague, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate calls on the Government to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from AUSTUDY by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.

I put it to the Government that, at the present time, its policies do not adequately take into account the hardship that is being suffered in so many rural areas. There are country towns at present which have just about collapsed completely. There is no money changing hands and there is genuine hardship in the rural communities and among the townspeople who, as a result of the rural recession, are not getting any money, are not able to survive and whose children will be seriously disadvantaged by the situation.

The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) referred to the Government's aim to increase retention at the secondary school level. All of us agree that that is a commendable aim. We have heard so often in recent years the Government boasting of the increase in retention levels. If increasing retention rates is to be an aim and something which is promoted as being very important to the education system, it is important that children who live in the country are not disadvantaged, that they have an equal opportunity of being retained to year 12 and are not merely discarded and thrown on the scrap heap. Many people at present are not able to offer their children the education that they would have hoped. They are not even able to put them in a neighbouring town or pay the boarding fees that would be necessary for them to live in a town nearby and go to a high school. That is something that we cannot allow to continue.

Some comments really need to be made about the motions that are before us today. Senator Lees's motion effectively abolishes the assets test. There has been discussion as to additional cost that would result.

If that money were to be made available, there are other ways in which it needs to be spent in the areas of education and health. It should not be spent on making Austudy a universal right of all students. That is the outcome that we believe should come out of this.

Senator Lees's motion does not really target rural and country students but targets all students. Some city students may be suffering hardship as well, but I believe they are able to be more easily catered for than are country students at the present time. I do not believe city students would be forced to give up their education in the same way that students from country towns and rural areas would be. While I do not suggest for a minute that Senator Lees is not sincere in what she is aiming to do, I believe that she is not going about it in a way which will benefit those people in the country areas who need help most.

Senator Bell's motion seeks to disallow about eight of the regulations. That would have an incredible impact. It seems to me that removing the age limit on Austudy to make it available for students of all ages may then make Austudy available to students who, while they certainly want to pursue an education, are not necessarily those who ought to be included in the target group. If Austudy were made virtually meaningless by leaving no rate for Austudy benefits, one can only conjecture what the impact would be. Perhaps it would mean that nobody would get anything or perhaps the Minister would be able to determine from time to time what the rate would be.

I would have thought that removing the special rate for the special living allowance is particularly relevant to the rural people whom the Australian Democrats say that they are attempting to assist. The Democrats also suggest making the independent rate available to younger students who fulfil the other criteria and making the independent rate available to students who are engaged in--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much audible conversation among Opposition senators. I am having difficulty hearing Senator Reid.

—They suggest making the independent rate available to students who are engaged in part time work or who are not in the work force at all and making Austudy available to all students, regardless of their earnings during the year. I cannot understand why that would be the effect of regulation 82. I cannot believe that is the best way to spend the education dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: Regulation 85 defines `parents' for the purpose of the income test, abolishing the parental income test and abolishing the spouse income test. Obviously, only limited money is available. I believe there is no possibility at the present time of this country being able to afford the money for Austudy that the Democrats would like. When one is not in government I guess it is easy to put forward a proposition which extends Austudy in this way and to say to people what one would like to be able to do if one was in government and if the country could afford it.

The most important thing for us at the present time is to see students, who would otherwise be deprived of education, getting access to the sort of money which may assist them in being able to stay at school. The long term benefit to them and to the country hardly needs to be spelled out.

We take the view that a number of aspects of Austudy need to be reviewed and we will do that when we are in government. We will review the administration of Austudy in order to overcome the administrative deficiencies and the allegations which we have all heard. One cannot go to a party anywhere without hearing about somebody getting Austudy who everybody else feels ought not to be getting it. Clearly, there needs to be a review in this area-either of the administration or of the way in which Austudy is made available-to see that some of these things do not occur.

We will see that there is a realistic assets test for Austudy which includes a hardship provision. I think we all need to recognise that hardship is something which occurs here and there from time to time. It can occur in a place such as Newcastle where, if there is an earthquake, there may be a need for specific hardship provisions for a period of time. The whole aim of social security, welfare payments, Austudy and things of this nature ought to be to assist people during times of hardship-during periods in people's lives when they need support and assistance for varying periods of time. There may be occasions when assistance needs to be applied in one part of Australia and not in another. But one has to be sufficiently imaginative to see that the benefit is given to those who need it.

We will certainly look at the isolated children's scheme. I have been quite appalled at the way that that has been handled in recent years. I feel that this Government has no understanding whatsoever of the plight of isolated children, as is seen by the way it has dealt with them. I think it is a great pity that those who live in areas where they do not have the same opportunities as city children are not being given the opportunity to pursue their education. There are other areas where isolated children have come to be disadvantaged during this period of the Labor Government. Fairness and equity are needed in these matters. We cannot indulge ourselves with expensive schemes which the Democrats-no doubt quite sincerely-would like to see.

It is not possible to make something like Austudy universal. I think most people in the community feel that it is of benefit and should be available. Students must get assistance, but not in a way which can be abused and which could see some students receiving it who ought not to be and others who live in the country towns and rural areas being deprived of education because of the circumstances of the economy at the present time.

Nobody is suggesting that Austudy should continue forever, but right now I think we all recognise that there are people in country areas who are not surviving. These people may have properties which, notionally, appear to be extremely valuable, but one test is to try to find a buyer for one of them. One of my colleagues mentioned earlier being told by the Department of Employment, Education and Training to sell part of a property. Who will buy part of it? It is absolute nonsense and it indicates to me that some people who are involved in this area have very little comprehension as to what life in the country is like and the state in which people are left when there is absolutely no value in a property.

A property which in the 1950s wool boom-that was 40-odd years ago-was extremely valuable may not be so valuable any more. Australia's mineral and rural exports are no longer bringing in the sort of money that they once did. But there are people in this country who still feel that if people live 50-odd miles out of town they are wealthy. That is not the case any more and anyone who has relatives living in the country, or who represents a rural electorate, knows what it is like to live in very difficult circumstances.

The last thing we want is to see the next generation of young people from the country disadvantaged by not being able to get an education. We need to see that those who need this money actually get it. I commend the motion that has been moved by Senator Teague. The Government should take an urgent and new look at the concept of hardship to see that its aim of having an increased number of students staying at school until at least year 12 in fact has some reality for those people who live outside the city areas.
