SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, but let me observe simply this: essentially, the assets test is an equitable criterion when considering taxation measures as distinct from equity and opportunity costs. The great tragedy of this debate is the very necessity for it, the very fact that there is a need presently to consider the income of the rural sector. The truth of the matter is that levels of assets for a great many rural producers are totally irrelevant in terms of the economic well-being of the producers or of their disposable incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a dramatic collapse in rural incomes and commodity prices. This year farmers' incomes are expected to decline by 67 per cent. According to the National Farmers Federation, the average farm income is expected to be $20,614, and, for wheat farmers, $3,875. It has reached the stage in parts of Western Australia-and I suspect that this is true of other parts of Australia-where finance companies are actually visiting farms and stations and physically collecting the cheque books. A pastoralist will be left on his station with no other source, no other capacity, to pay for his daily needs or to maintain the ongoing activity of his farm. Elders Finance or whichever company takes the cheque book and says, `This is the most painless way that we can ensure that you do not damage yourself or us for the future', is simply cutting the umbilical, simply cutting the capacity to function.

In many respects commodity prices are outside the control of Australian producers. It may well be said that wheat prices are likely to rebound in the next year or two and that this year is an aberration, although that cannot be said of wool prices. They will be depressed for the medium to long term. But what this Government does have control over, what this Government does have a capacity to influence, is the free on board cost of goods. In other words, it has the capacity to influence net profits as distinct from gross profits. It has control over interest rates, inflation, transport costs, unit labour costs and waterfront costs, yet thus far it has done absolutely nothing.

The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) is in the chamber. In the case of waterfront reform, we are seeing a repetition of what we saw immediately following containerisation of the waterfront. The number of employees was reduced. There was a surplus to demand, a surplus to need of labour, but during that period the income of waterside workers went up dramatically. When we are supposed to be having reform in order to get rid of the bizarre practices, the bizarre rip-offs and the bizarre costs on the waterfront, the price of reform has been blackmail.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) dashed down in his jet from sunny Northern Territory to take Senator Collins by the hand and finally negotiate a blackmail deal which, in essence, says, `If you make some modest gains so that on 6 May I look good, we will ensure that you have a substantially improved income for the following 12 months'. In other words, the price for doing the obvious, natural, reasonable thing was to set the waterside workers aside from everybody else, to be subject to blackmail and to give them substantial benefits simply for doing the right thing.

At the end of the day, efficiency on the waterfront will still be dragging way behind that of the rest of the world. Then we have transport costs other than the waterfront. We can go into the costs of shipping, even down to New Zealand, of course. Senator Collins has not yet addressed that; he has not told us what he intends to do about the cosy deal between the Waterside Workers Federation and the seamen's unions of Australia and New Zealand, and the bizarre practices that are carried on.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's this got to do with Austudy?

—Let me tell Senator Lees what it has to do with Austudy. It has to do with the cost and the capacity of the rural sector to pay its own way. The reason the Australian Democrats are now trying to make cheap political points arises from the dire circumstances in which the rural economy finds itself. Not only has its assets collapsed, but so has its net income each year. Presumably, that is why Senator Lees is arguing for the disallowance in the way she is, because of the incapacity of the rural sector to pay. I am setting out some areas that are within the influence and capacity of the Government to put right. The tragedy is that we are arguing about a smaller and reduced cake. We are in the gutter arguing about social welfare needs because this Government has destroyed the economy. We would not be here debating this issue if the economy were set in the right direction. It is absurd not to look at the macro-economic considerations. I turn to unit labour costs, for instance. Between 1983 and 1990 those costs have risen--
—You are not going to change that today. You have an opportunity to do something useful now.
—Senator Bell says that we will not change that position tonight. He is quite right but, come the revolution, he will see change, even if it makes the Democrats, with respect, irrelevant.
—What's all this talk about revolution?
—Revolution does not only come with a red shirt. It comes with a brown shirt and with a blue shirt.
—Which colour are you wearing?

—I am in my normal traditional blue, but deep below that one will find a tinge of green. Between 1983 and 1990, unit labour costs in Australia have increased by 45 per cent. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average is 20 per cent. Our figure is double, and we want to know why we cannot compete. We want to know why farmers, people in the rural sector and in the rural community and country towns, are in their present dire circumstances, when the costs of labour in Australia are double the figure anywhere else. One wonders why interest rates are where they are. In notional terms they have come down four or five points in the past few months, but in real terms interest rates in Australia are holding high. Why are they holding high? It is because of the fragility of the Australian dollar, combined with the level of inflation.
—Incompetence of this Government.

—Acknowledging the interjection, the general incompetence and incapacity of this Government leave it totally paralysed and unable to do that which needs to be done. Thanks to the accord, we have an inflationary floor underneath wages. We have seen notional wages running at around 6 per cent for the average worker, but in real terms-in terms of pay in the pocket-the average worker has been worse off every single year that this Government has been in power, yet the notional costs shunt into the costs for the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, when all this is happening, we see youth unemployment where it is. The number of young people receiving unemployment benefit in April last year was 393,900, and in April of this year it jumped to 616,300-double. Over 600,000 young people are now receiving unemployment benefit. How depressing that is. Youth unemployment between the ages of 15 and 19 is three times higher than it is for adults. It is presently running at around 27 per cent.

In this important debate I do not want to score any political points and it is not in my nature to do so, but I wish, with respect, to observe one thing. The poorest electorates in Australia are represented by the Liberal and National parties-without exception. Talk about our understanding and empathising with the voters. It is not without significance to note that those electorates almost without exception are in the country. Those are the areas which are presently suffering as a result of the incompetence, failings and incapacity of this Government.

I conclude by saying that I have always understood education to be a universal right for everybody. It ought not be a liability to parents to raise children in the country. It ought not be any great privilege to send children from isolated country towns to the metropolitan area to receive the same education as that received by their cousins who happen to live in the city and who are able to go as day boys to Scotch College, Wesley or Christchurch or Balga High School--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Aquinas.

—Or even Aquinas. It ought not be a privilege to have that same opportunity. It is not good enough to say, `Well, they can stay in dormitories and go to high schools in the rural centres', because in many cases, thanks to the ongoing failings of so many Labor State governments, they do not have the infrastructure. The facilities are not there, and therefore the opportunities are not there. I shall not be distracted in this debate to talk about the inadequacy of the isolated children's allowance, but if I were to be distracted I would make certain points-but I am only tempted, Mr Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I thoroughly support Senator Teague's amendment to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from Austudy by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds. The tragedy is that that statistic is already moving. There are already a great many parents who are required to withdraw their children from a college education in the metropolitan area simply because they cannot afford to feed them in the schools-they cannot afford to pay the bills. Those children are being required to go back home and have some sort of extended education program that puts them at a significant disadvantage compared with those people who live in the metropolitan areas. If it were not for the economic circumstances cast on this community like a great depressing cloud, we would not be required to debate the circumstances as we are. But to the extent that we are debating this matter, I support Senator Teague's amendment without qualification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking against Senator Lees's motion to disallow Austudy regulations 13 to 20, I believe that it is worth prefacing my remarks with the comment that it would appear, at least to the coalition, that the Australian Democrats have shown some concern and that, at last, the Australian Labor Party is to commission a report into Austudy. Therefore, the parties in this chamber at least realise that Austudy as it operates at present is simply chaotic. If reports in the Sunday Age are accurate-and I certainly hope they are-it appears that at last the Government has recognised that this is a major problem area. But it is obvious that we all have very different ways of expressing what needs to be done to overcome the problems with Austudy. The Government is proposing a review which will be completed by, it anticipates, September this year. However, I make the point that that is too late for those in rural Australia. They need help now, not next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Austudy was developed for all the right reasons but, as time has shown, the wrong practical emphasis has applied. There are loopholes big enough to drive a bus through. From the number of fraudulent claims that the Austudy section of the Department of Employment, Education and Training spends its time unravelling, it seems that the loopholes are not just huge but also easy to find by anyone wishing to rort the system. For example, I want to read to the Senate a copy of a letter I received from a deputy principal of a school, highlighting the inadequacies of the system and to indicate how some people are rorting the system. It gives the reason why we should not be proceeding down the track that Senator Lees is currently proposing to the Senate. The letter states:
Dear Sir,
Jane D-
and I will use that expression to describe the person-
was an enrolled student at this school in 1990, and was processed as a leaver on 30 November.

On 4 February 1991 she reappeared, saying that she wished to re-enrol. She was given the appropriate forms, and was entered on our roll. She told us that her start would be delayed by medical treatment.

After several weeks during which she did not attend we heard reports that led us to ask if she intended to be a student. When she replied in the negative, her name was removed from our roll as of 1 March.
Jane D thus was on our roll for four weeks in 1991, but as she did not attend school we cannot say that she has been a student this year.
We leave the decision to you as to whether you wish to recoup money she has received.

If we had learned earlier that she was claiming Austudy, we would have investigated her non-attendance more vigilantly. Unfortunately, we are not notified until the end of term, by which time a fraudulent applicant could have received a large sum of money difficult to recoup.
Is it possible for Austudy to verify a claim earlier in the process, before paying so much money to the applicant?

That letter, as addressed to the Department of Employment, Education and Training in South Australia, highlighted a problem in the system, how the system is open to abuse, and why we should not be proceeding down the path proposed by Senator Lees.

At the same time as the loopholes are embracing the unworthy, to which I have just referred, the regulations are shutting out some sections of the extremely needy in the community. In my State, specifically in the rural sector, many families which have book assets of land and machinery that they cannot sell have been deemed to be too asset-rich to access Austudy. It is a cruel situation that should be redressed, for while these families may indeed have assets on paper they cannot in fact be realised. Nor can they even be borrowed against, because those families are earning little or no income during the present troubles in rural areas.

If one does not have an income one cannot get a loan, and I do not need to emphasise to the Senate that the banks have retreated into very conservative lending practices, given their experiences in the 1980s. Farmers cannot obtain carry-on funds, as their assets have depreciated substantially over the past year or two. So they have no asset value on which to secure a loan and they have no income with which to repay the loan, and therefore they cannot access a loan. It is a vicious catch 22 cycle that these people in rural Australia and rural South Australia are caught in. In other words, I suppose, they have assets which in these economic times are quite worthless, except when it comes to claiming government help such as Austudy, and then those assets are deemed to be a reason for excluding support, when that support ought to be forthcoming.

It saddens me that, while there is a genuine problem with Austudy regulations, which we must overcome if Austudy is to be fairly and properly doing the job which it was meant to do and which it was developed for, we have to understand that that is not why we have these motions before the Senate. The Democrats' motion to abolish the assets test is a grab for publicity back home in South Australia and elsewhere in rural Australia. Senator Lees has been putting the Democrats' view and creating false hopes on the part of farming families who are already greatly distressed by the rural crisis. They are false hopes, and Senator Lees knows it. They have been told that it is only the Democrats who will get rid of the Austudy assets test so that the asset rich but income poor families may qualify.

However, Senator Lees never actually mentioned that the Democrats did not vote against the introduction of the assets test in the first place, nor, while we are talking about the Democrats engendering false hopes, has she told those families that her Party's policy is to apply death duties on all properties over $300,000 in value, that her Party supports a capital gains tax and a Federal land tax, and that it intends to cut funds to non-government schools. It certainly would not take a wool or wheat crisis or a drought to ruin Australia's rural areas-just a few months of Democrat policies would do that quite successfully.

Over the past months, I have witnessed a considerable amount of concern and dejection amongst rural people as to the sort of direction and promises put forward and, more importantly, I think, the false hopes that have been created for these people in rural Australia. Unlike the Democrats, who promise the world but know that they will never be in a position where they actually have to deliver it, we believe in our policies being responsible. I hope that Senator Lees will not do a quick clip of today's Hansard and splash the debate around the South Australian countryside in an attempt to set the perception that she is the only person in Federal Parliament who will take action to help people in the rural sector to access Austudy. To do so would be absolutely hypocritical. It would be hypocritical because even a fleeting glance at the motion indicates that it is not real. The matter has not been researched thoroughly.

If Senator Lees actually meant there to be serious debate in this chamber on such a motion, she would at least have narrowed it down to removing the assets test only for the rural families in need. But, no, as the motion stands, Senator Lees wants to open the Austudy floodgates to wide abuse. I have referred to one abuse already. Her motion, if passed, would have meant no assets test on Austudy for anyone, anywhere: none for the city or country people, regardless of economic circumstances. That, to me, is opportunism. A school student could tell Senator Lees that abolition of the assets test would only worsen Austudy's unfairness, for it is obvious that the rich who live on assets would benefit. If abolished it would cost the country another $60m minimum a year, and I am told that that is a conservative figure, not allowing for the abuse factor that might apply.

Where would the money come from? Who on another social welfare program suffers to allow this suggestion of the Democrats to proceed? It would weaken the targeting of Austudy to those in need, as thousands more families who most definitely do not need help and yet meet the Democrats' criteria put their hands out. It would allow further misdirection of funds. As I have said already, it is opening the floodgates to abuse.

Of course, the rural sector needs help at present, and in the present rural crisis incomes have been drastically reduced. In many cases producers can expect negative incomes this year. Their assets are not an indication of their income earning capacity, and special provisions are appropriate at this time. My colleague Senator Teague and other speakers have referred to the hardship provisions that need to be put in place at this time without opening the floodgates to abuse.

There is also a need to ensure that country people access higher levels of education. If one looks at the participation rates in higher education per head of population, one will find variations according to region, those figures being highest for people in urban areas, lower for those in rural areas and lower still for people in remote areas. Those results have occurred as a result of relating the figures to a population base. The basic hierarchy is similar for all age groups, both sexes and across all States. In other words, we are not ensuring that country people and people who live in remote areas have the same access to education as their city counterparts.

For that reason, we need properly targeted support and assistance for people to access education. If ever there were a need for country people to increase their level of education capacity and ability it is right now. This will enable them to cope with the crisis confronting them now and over the next 10 years or so. We must give every encouragement to higher levels of education throughout rural Australia. I am sure that no-one would argue about achieving that objective.

We need to target the support. In a couple of years it may be some other sector that needs targeting in response to a particular set of circumstances. Any changes to Austudy must be carefully targeted only to the sector with the hardship; hence the proposal put forward by Senator Teague. No-one benefits from a superficial, ill considered motion, such as we have before us today.

Having spent most of my life in a country area, having members of my direct family still receiving education in country areas of South Australia and having had business interests in country areas of South Australia that have been dramatically affected by present circumstances, not only in economic terms but also in personal terms, I cannot identify to Senator Lees how angry I have become during the past few months about such subjects as the plight of the rural sector, Austudy and the peddling of false hopes to those people. I take exception to the way in which this matter has been handled.

What Senator Lees has done in recent months in my State epitomises everything that gives politicians a bad name within our community. Changes to Austudy have to be fair to the rural community and, I stress, equally fair to the community generally, to the taxpayers who are paying for the scheme. As politicians, we represent each and every one of them, not just those pockets of people who we hope may vote or continue to vote for us. For reasons of compassion for the plight of the rural sector and an awareness of the economic situation in which we find ourselves through the inadequacies of the Labor Government, the critical Austudy inadequacies must be addressed by the insertion of hardship clauses in the Austudy regulations. That needs to be done now, not when a report comes out in September-and the Government will take between three and six months to act upon it-so that the net effect is not felt until some time next year.

The coalition has already called upon the Government to treat this as a matter or urgency. The shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), has indicated quite clearly and specifically that hardship provisions are needed now. All parties recognise there are problems with Austudy, so why is it so difficult for the Government to take some deliberative, determined action to correct what are clearly inadequacies in the system that are directly affecting a section of the community that is now all but helpless because of economic circumstances that have descended upon its shoulders? There have to be hardship provisions so that those who deserve help can access it, not so that more people can abuse the public purse, which will be the end result of the motion that is before us tonight.

The coalition has asked the Government that families, who are being forced to withdraw their children from formal education on financial grounds and who would not otherwise be eligible for Austudy on the ground of the value of assets, receive assistance on a case by case basis. From a personal point of view, I believe that there are workable long term hardship clauses for target groups, such as the rural sector at present, which should at least be considered for Austudy. I shall give an example. If, after averaging its income with assets over the previous five years, a family met the existing Austudy income criteria for families without assets, that family could and should be treated as having nil assets for as long as the five years applied for the family income test level. In that way, we would apply the income test level that is applicable in the metropolitan area to people in the country areas, so that we target help directly to people who can demonstrate that need. We do not open the gates wholly to areas of abuse which, once the gates were opened, could and would be abused.

Then there is the higher education contribution scheme for target groups proposed by the honourable member for Wakefield, Mr Andrew, as another alternative, another type of hardship provision, that could be implemented by the Government to address the current crisis. Either of those two suggestions would remove the assets component difficulty for families deemed to be in target groups in temporary need- `in need' being the two important words.

The Democrats' way is to tackle that by proposing a motion to give away millions of taxpayers' dollars to anyone who puts out a hand. The right way is for an immediate hardship clause to be inserted that properly targets areas of need. That is coalition policy and we urge the Government, yet again, to move in that direction, and to move fast. Meanwhile there are many potential ways to alter the Austudy regulations which are worthy of further discussion by all parties. I have mentioned two here tonight. I hope that Senator Lees and the Democrats recognise that other members of the Senate from other parties also have a very genuine and real concern for the plight of country people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do it tonight.

—We want to do something. In doing something, let us do it positively, deliberatively. Let us do it so that it does not open the floodgates. Let us target the assistance to those who are in need and deserve that assistance, and not just make a quick grab for a headline by opening up the floodgates with a $60m bottom line to government, and a possibility of further abuse. Senator Bell is just proposing a billion dollars extra expenditure--
—One point two billion.

—That is right. I do not know how much research Senator Bell did before preparing his motion but strike a light, I would hate to have him running the Treasury. I know that we are in enough trouble with Treasurer Keating but, goodness gracious, if we ever had the misfortune to have Senator Bell as the Treasurer of this country, we would have massive problems. He has here a $1.2 billion spending exercise in one motion that he puts before the Senate. Who knows what other areas might cross his desk from time to time?

SPEECH.PARA: That just demonstrates the way in which the Democrats have approached this whole subject area: with little thought to the bottom line; with little thought of the responsibility to all taxpayers; with scant thought for those in need. Their proposal is superficial, not the substance that will address the real needs of people in rural Australia. Addressing those needs is the direction that the coalition is proposing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Teague which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate calls on the Government to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship conditions so that families excluded from AUSTUDY by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.

I had hoped that the amendment moved by Senator Teague would get the support of the Australian Democrats. It is a responsible amendment. It deals with all of those problems which were raised so well by Senator Olsen and Senator Crichton-Browne and it will meet the needs of many rural families who are suffering very great hardship at the present time.

I rise tonight to speak briefly about a matter that was raised by Senator Olsen when he spoke about Senator Lees going around country areas and raising false hopes amongst rural families. I have recently been to a meeting which was attended mainly by wheat farmers and sheep farmers in a country town in the mid-west of Victoria. The issue raised with me at that meeting was the matter of the Austudy proposal that Senator Lees has been going around the Australian countryside promoting. What I said to this meeting, and I think it is worth recording here this evening, is that the Australian Democrats' policies pretend to give major concessions to rural families but that, in essence, their policies are anti-rural and effectively discriminate against rural families.

If I may explain that: after mentioning the enormous cost of the sorts of proposals that Senator Lees and Senator Bell are proposing, I asked people at this meeting, `Where do you think this money is going to come from?'. Senator Collins has just pointed out that it is $1.2 billion. I pointed out to these people, `If you believe that you are better off with a wealth tax; if you believe that marginal tax rates on incomes are too low in this country; if you believe in the reintroduction of death duties; and if you believe that we need to have a wealth tax, then you will vote for the Australian Democrats'. There is no question about that.

The logic suddenly became very evident to people at the meeting: one can promise to hand out money but it has to be paid for. The reality is that the Australian Democrats are proposing a series of taxes which will have particularly savage effects on rural families. There are over 40 revenue raising measures in the Democrats' alternative Budget, but one particular proposal that will certainly hit not only rural families but also the vast proportion of families in this country is the proposal to have a capital gains tax on the family home.

In my view, if the Democrats have a tax policy which imposes very heavy taxes on people, they should stand up and defend it. The Democrats should not come in here pretending that they can spend billions of dollars of taxpayers' funds without proposing ways to raise this money. This is a debate about a very real problem in the midst of a very real crisis. Senator Teague, to his great credit, has moved a motion which will help alleviate some of the most serious problems which have emerged. I would have thought the Australian Democrats would be prepared to get up and support it, but they are not.

It distresses me that the debate we are having is, unfortunately, enabling a bit of grandstanding on the part of both Senator Lees and Senator Bell by pretending that they have the interests of rural families at heart. If Senator Lees has the interests of rural families at heart, why does she propose all these taxes, which will particularly hurt rural families? Why does Senator Lees continue to support things like bans on live sheep exports, which will certainly hurt many people in the sheep industry? Particularly, why does Senator Lees support measures which come before this Parliament which will increase trade union power and privilege? Those are the issues.

The Democrats individually cannot go around saying `We have this nice policy to help rural families' when the vast range of their other policies is very anti-rural. I suggest to both Senator Lees and Senator Bell that they speak to their colleagues Senator Spindler and Senator Paul McLean and ask them to bring their policies into line to assist rural families, not to penalise rural families. I believe that the amendment which has been moved by Senator Teague should be strongly supported. I regret, judging by the comments that we are now getting from the Australian Democrats, that the amendment will not enjoy their support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to close the debate tonight on the motion I moved on the Austudy regulations 13 to 20. If the motion is opposed tonight, the assets test will not be removed from Austudy. I begin by answering some of the nonsense that has been spoken particularly by Senator Kemp tonight. We have no death duties and no Federal land tax. Senator Spindler has a copy of our alternative Budget in the chamber. Senator Kemp might like to try to find the page that has anything at all about the tax on the family home.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators of some of the coalition's tax policies. In particular, the coalition's consumption tax will see a tax on a luxury car at the same rate as a tax on a loaf of bread. How will country people feel about having such high taxes on all the items that they have to buy from the local supermarket?

As for strike action, there is a very big difference between responsible and irresponsible strikes. The Democrats are planning, through our move for the right to strike, to make very definite and distinct differences between what can be enforced and responsible action. In other words, we will still give people the right to meet and to associate without having the threat of action over their heads.

I refer to some comments made by Senator Teague, which are at the heart of the problem. Senator Teague was basically asking us to wait. He said very clearly that we must push and encourage the Government. He talked about urging the Government to act; he talked about hoping that the Government would act; and he talked a lot about helping those who are suffering in the rural communities. On those particular issues, we support him fully. But we cannot keep hoping, urging and wishing that the Government will do something.

Here is the opportunity tonight. Senator Teague's amendment seeks to amend my motion. I will explain why we cannot support it. Senator Teague's amendment calls on the Government to act, which is a little more active than hoping, but it still will not achieve anything tonight. On looking at this amendment again, I suggest that Senator Teague should move it as an urgency motion tomorrow. We will support him wholeheartedly. We can debate at length again all the issues we have debated tonight. Most of the issues have been covered very successfully. If Senator Teague moves an urgency motion tomorrow, that is fine, but we will not accept a motion which takes the place of action. The reason that we will not support Senator Teague's amendment tonight is that it removes any compulsion on the Government. Senator Teague has indicated that he will be moving a motion tomorrow, and we welcome that debate. It is a very promising and pleasing sign.

Senator Teague raised a number of other points. He quoted from today's Adelaide Advertiser. Fortunately, we have had a dinner break since Senator Teague spoke and I managed to get back to my office and find the article. The problem of these hardship provisions is well known to all the rural counsellors in South Australia. I can talk specifically about South Australia because I have had some discussions with a number of the rural counsellors.

The catch is that, although there are hardship provisions in the regulations, they are almost impossible to access. A couple of months ago my office informally surveyed the Department of Social Security (DSS) offices in regional South Australia. We cannot find a farmer who has managed to access them readily. Why? I will read part of the survey for the benefit of Senator Teague:
. . . cannot reasonably be expected to sell his property or to use as security for borrowings. They must put their property on the market.

Farmers do not want to put their properties on the market. Not wanting to come here tonight with a survey that was a couple of months old, I got my staff to ring around the DSS offices again. After ringing Kadina, Port Augusta, Port Lincoln, Port Pirie and Whyalla, we have come up with one farmer who has in fact applied and is still going through the process of hopefully getting hardship provisions. But the comment was that he does not have a very good chance.

Today my office also contacted the Adelaide Welfare Rights Centre. Its comment was that of course no-one is applying under the hardship provisions. People are told at the counter that they must apply for household assistance, again available to those people who are going off the land. They are being turned away and one reason for this is that the Department does not like paying any special benefits. So hardship provisions have their own set of problems.

On the question of unemployment benefits, because property values have dropped so much and because the DSS system of valuing properties is far superior to that of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, some farmers have got in under the assets test, but have failed the work test. They are deemed to be underemployed, not unemployed. A lot of them are not told that in fact their wives should apply for unemployment benefits. I have found several cases, particularly on Kangaroo Island, where wives have successfully managed to get unemployment benefits, despite all the hurdles and the number of applications and appeals.

In looking at some of the things that have been said about valuations, I cannot stress strongly enough that there is no relevance between the value of the land, the buildings, the stock, and the machinery and what the farmer is able to earn. That point has been made extremely well by members of the coalition. A number of speakers have dealt at great length with the hardships that people in rural Australia are now facing. Tools of trade should not be included in the valuation of assets.

If we look at the valuation problems-and Senator O'Chee highlighted this when he read from a document that I put together-the easiest way to deal with them is to get rid of the initial problem, which is the assets test. Senator O'Chee also pointed out quite correctly that if we are not successful with this motion tonight, the next direction in which we can move is to tackle the method of valuation of the Australian Valuation Office (AVO). Relaxing the assets test is all we want initially but, if that is not successful, we must tackle what the AVO has been doing.

We must particularly tackle the element of retrospectivity. Why should farmers apply in good faith, using State valuations, council valuations or Elders valuations, get their Austudy and then not only have it cut off by a retrospective valuation, but then have to pay it back? If this move is not successful tonight-and it seems that it will not be-the next course of action for the Democrats is to tackle the system of valuation.

With regard to some comments that have been made about our being forced to take out the entire assets test, one would have hoped that honourable senators-particularly some of the long standing senators who have spoken tonight-would have had a thorough understanding of the way this place works. We cannot amend regulations. All we can do is throw them out. I can assure honourable senators that a government that has cut $8 billion cumulative from social security is not going to let $1,000, let alone a couple of million dollars, slip through its fingers. The Government will have the whole assets section rewritten and have the regulations back, I imagine, within weeks and six months at the latest.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be six months.

—Within that six months, very few people will be able to get into universities because they are full. The technical and further education colleges are full to overflowing. The only people who would benefit would be a small number of students who have taken the risk and, despite their parents' low income, have gone on to tertiary education without any Austudy support. As Senator Olsen pointed out, many of those people will have to leave. So in the few months that it may take us to get regulations back before this House, there would be a very small leakage, if any. I totally reject Senator Olsen's suggestion that somehow this is opening the gates for manipulation so that people can actually fraudulently claim. I reject any notion that farming communities would be likely to do that. Senator Olsen's suggestion that, by opening this up, we would see an increase is nonsense, although he did read one example of how the Austudy system had been rorted.

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to point out what happened with therapeutic goods. Some honourable senators have spoken on this matter since dinner and they were obviously not in the chamber when I last dealt with this issue. When Senator Coulter spoke on this matter, he explained how the regulations were thrown out and then, with considerable consultation and discussion, they were brought back in and passed through this place without any further problems. The same thing could happen and should happen with the Austudy regulations. We throw them out tonight and, if we were able to amend them in the way we wish, that is, to exclude farming families who live and work on their own property and the non-liquid assets of small business people, the total cost would be $26m. But that total cost would only come in if every eligible rural person was able to access.

The first hurdle is that even Austudy will not give some country families access to education. Their incomes are so low that, even with Austudy, many of their children are not going to be able to make it, particularly to tertiary education. Even the first hurdle of matriculating may still be beyond some country students. This $26m takes no account of that. We see in South Australia that roughly one-third of applicants who wanted to get into tertiary institutions did not make it. So we see that more people will fall by the wayside.

If people do get over all those hurdles and if they matriculate with a good enough pass to get into tertiary education-and the Minister earlier told us that some 48 per cent of students are on Austudy-there is almost a fifty-fifty chance that they will in fact replace someone already getting Austudy. So we see very quickly that this $26m is probably down to more like $10m. If Senator Teague keeps his promise and the Liberal Party does something when it comes into government-and the opinion polls suggest that it will do so in 1993-we will have lost the students in this year's grades 8, 9 and 10, who by then, three years hence, will have made their decisions with regard to their future. Many of them will have opted out.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can act now.
—We cannot act now.
—You can accept the amendment.

—The amendment will do nothing. I will quote from it again, if it will make Senator Teague happy. It reads: `calling on the Government'. We can call all night. We can sit here until 2 o'clock in the morning and we can keep calling. The Government has shown no sign at all of moving on this issue. So, by moving the amendment and continuing to call, we are simply wasting our breath. It all becomes more and more hot air. We need action and we will happily join Opposition members. This is an urgency motion and getting it down on paper at a later time is fine but here and now we are debating something that we can do. We can actually remove these specific parts of the regulations, send them off for rewriting and then, when they come back, hopefully they will be in an acceptable form. Again, going back to the issue of therapeutic goods, if discussion is involved, they will be in that form and we can pass them through this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other points were raised and people kept referring to furphies, trying to distract us from what the issue is here to night. I will not go through them because I know that Senator Bell is going to pick up a number of them. I say to the Senate that we have a chance to make this place work. We have a chance to actually do something that will make a difference. I hope that honourable senators will think again before deciding that hot air is far more valuable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that I had a few moments after Senator Olsen finished speaking to quell my anger. I agreed with him when he began his speech and said that September was too late for reforms, that there were loopholes and that there was abuse. He then proceeded to state our case quite admirably-the case of the rural community, the people who live on farms and derive their income from rural properties and who are, to use what is now a cliche, asset rich and income poor. However, he offered excuses as to why we should do nothing in this place tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Lees has just said, Senator Olsen, in referring to abuses, somehow ascribed to the process of what is being proposed here tonight a greater opportunity for absences from college. I really could not see the relevance of that and that is what started to make me angry and, as his speech continued, I became angrier. The relief was that I had a chance to regain my composure before closing this debate.

The Australian Democrats support a comprehensive review of the Austudy scheme and the establishment of a scheme which is simple and which promotes greater access and equity. One of the tactics which we could have used, and which could have worked, would have been for the coalition to have supported us in the lead-up to this debate by suggesting that it was prepared to agree with us, that the proposed new Austudy regulations were worthy of being disallowed. If that threat had been held over the Government's head we may even have seen the process that Senator Lees described-the process of rewriting and revision to make these regulations workable, useful, equitable and sensible.

Vast sums of money-I cannot quantify them; they were significant at least-could have been saved if the scheme had been simplified. We are talking about a scheme which requires an applicant to answer almost 100 questions. The application can be rejected if any one of those questions is not properly answered, if a question is answered in an ambiguous fashion, or if the processing clerk does not understand what is being put forward. So the opportunity to have a system which does not work starts on the very first page of the application. Considerable sums of clerical, bureaucratic and taxpayers' money could have been saved if this opportunity had been taken not only to write these regulations in plain English but also to remove the inefficiencies that exist in their very administration. The opportunity was not taken.

However, it was very strange that during the debate we heard of a leaked document, or at least a partly understood document, which Senator Olsen again referred to. In the early part of his speech I nodded in agreement with him, that this sort of thing needed to be considered carefully. We heard of a leaked document, or at least a document in preparation. Yesterday's Sunday Age, in an article headed `Austudy may get radical changes' by Michael Gordon, reported:
A Government document outlining the scope of the review highlights many criticisms of the scheme, including its impact on farming families and administrative problems such as overpayment and fraud.

The document obtained yesterday by the Sunday Age says that it is time to consider whether the current scheme remains appropriate or whether some alternative or modified form of student income support should be introduced. That is a very strange thing to happen in the middle of this debate. The debate started when these regulations were first introduced into the Senate. While that was happening, while our motions of disallowance were impending, at the very last stroke before midnight we saw this matter coming forward without our knowledge and without warning. If there is to be a review, as suggested by this document, we do not want Austudy made worse in the interim. We do not want it made particularly nasty and restrictive in the interim. A wise government, I would have thought, would have left it alone so that it would not suffer the criticisms which derive from these proposed regulations by reducing the amount of income which a spouse can earn from $18,150 to $12,150 before affecting the entitlement of his or her partner to Austudy. If a review of this nature was impending, as illustrated by this newspaper article, I would have thought that a wise government would have avoided the criticism, got on with the review and left in place the regulations which were originally in place.

That draws me to the point that the Democrats were not standing idly by during this process and hoping that that was the only string to our bow. We have approached the office of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) about the need for the Student Assistance Review Tribunal and its operations. At the moment its operations are patently unsatisfactory. To allow the Student Assistance Review Tribunal to be given discretionary power to override some of the stringent Austudy rules enable the actions of those hardship provisions which exist at the moment to have been made much easier. The hardship provisions which exist at the moment are, as Senator Lees said, almost impossible to activate.

Coalition members come into this place and wave about a bit of paper which has on it some half-baked suggestion that we are going to call on the Government to do something about hardship provisions. This Government will say that there are hardship provisions. The Democrats were trying to find a way of getting those hardship provisions which exist to work. In addition, there were other provisions within the general scope of the legislation which, as Senator Bolkus repeatedly told the Senate, gave the opportunity for those in financial hardship to receive emergency interim payments as a sort of bridge.

Several times we were told that such provisions existed. In all my dealings with young people, student unions and people representing young people, I did not find anybody who had found access to that particular hardship proviso. The Opposition suggests that just by calling on the Government to provide more hardship provisions it will somehow solve the immediate problem of those in rural Australia. As Senator Lees said, we can cooee, we can yell, we can beat the drum and do what we like, but it is proposed here to call on the Government to do something. I think the response would be one of cloth ears.

As Senator Teague said, the proposed action is direct and immediate. Those are fine sounding words. I do not class the amendment he moved, whereby he calls on the Government to do something, as being direct and immediate. It may be direct if he intended to do it tonight, but its result will certainly not be direct and immediate.

Senator Olsen used emotive words when describing the problem that we have as being a cruel one that must be addressed. Another cliche that was thrown around with abandon tonight was the idea that false hope was being perpetrated in the rural areas of Australia. The only false hope is that any action will actually take place. It is a hope which could be rock hard, true and tangible tonight if only the coalition would realise that all that is required of it is to agree with us and disallow these regulations. Then there will be action. There will be no hope about it; it will take place and there will be immediate relief.

However, we have this other half-baked amendment before us which I cannot support tonight. It is inappropriate. It is in the wrong forum. It does not belong here. If the Opposition puts up the motion tomorrow-for all that it is worth-it will get the support of the Democrats. Greater, more useful, tangible activity would result from supporting our motion for the disallowance of the assets test component in so far as Senator Lees is concerned and the other aspects as far as I am concerned.

There is another matter which needs to be addressed. There are two separate motions for disallowance: the motion which Senator Lees moved on another day, a day other than the one on which I moved a motion-a motion which was intended to be debated in another context-and a motion which, if passed, would result in the removal of the assets test, not the income test.

I saw honourable senators waving their arms about and creating all sorts of flurry and fluster about opening the floodgates. No. The assets test removed, alone, would not allow those who have high incomes immediately to acquire the privileges of Austudy. It would have brought relief to those who are, as Senator Olsen described them, asset rich and income poor. It would not have brought a sudden flood of wealthy, high income people into this category.

That is why we separated these two notices of motion; that is why we wanted these things discussed separately; that is why we divided over the issue of the cognate debate; and that is why I presented a separate argument from the argument presented by Senator Lees. The confusion that the Opposition suffered over the matter is a confusion which it could well have removed by understanding what was being proposed and by not acceding to the rearrangement of Government Business so that there was a cognate debate on these two motions.

A further confusion was perpetrated by other honourable senators, especially members of the coalition, who brought into the debate the isolated children's allowance. We had a good, solid 10 minutes from Senator O'Chee about that, and several other honourable senators mentioned it in passing. The fact is that the isolated children's allowance-which we would prefer to call the isolated children's entitlement-receives the Democrats' strong support, and a suggestion by anybody that that has anything to do with this particular debate is erroneous, misleading and dishonest because it paints an entirely different picture from that which is, in fact, true.

Talking of things that are untrue and irrelevant, it is a pity that Senator Teague had to resort to fictional composition to alarm voters with the worst things that he could dream up and then disguise those horrendous things as Democrat policy. I could invent here tonight a whole bunch of Liberal policies. I would not be doing anything different from what is being done by Dr Hewson quite often-inventing policies on the run. I could invent policies which suggest that there be a tax on the family television or free privileges for certain people-anybody whose name starts with `T' could get a doubling of salary.

I could invent policies, but I certainly cannot produce, in Democrat policies-which are written, which are tangible and which, unlike a lot of coalition policies, are actually on paper-evidence of the sort of alarmist garbage that we heard from coalition speakers time after time. There is no mention-and there never has been-of a capital gains tax on the family home. Anybody who can identify that as a Democrat policy has looked at policies that certainly I have never taken part in promoting or forming.

That fiction is a very dishonest, guttersnipe fiction which is perpetrated far too often by people that I have to refer to as `honourable senators', and it sticks in my craw to have to do that. I find it insulting in the extreme for people to come in here, invent policies and then claim that we hold them. Our policies are written down, they are in black and white and we stand by them. They do not include the sort of trash that was thrown around tonight. The anger that I felt when hearing that has been very hard to contain.

The rest of the debate seemed to follow a fairly predictable pattern. In fact, there was a predictable performance from Senator O'Chee. It amuses me to think about it. Sitting next to Senator Bjelke-Petersen might make it a little easier for Senator O'Chee, and it might help him to ask Senator Bjelke-Petersen what a blancmange is. I think she would describe it to him as something which is fairly vacuous, appears attractive on the outside but really is not substantial. I am reminded of that when I think of the contribution that Senator O'Chee made. There really was not a lot of content-there were a lot of crocodile tears but I think they only served to dissolve the blancmange. His contribution was predictable.

I turn to Senator Crane's contribution. I thought that Senator Crane made a perfect case for the removal of the assets test. He described the volatility of farm values, and I think he was accurate in that. I agree with him. That is the very reason for removing the assets test from Austudy measurements. Senator Crane read out a set of figures the relevance of which I did not understand. I think he was supporting the Government and saying that the present expenditure on education is wonderfully adequate in comparison with some other countries. We know that that is not true; we know that it is not adequate; thousands of students know that it is not adequate; and the families of those students know that it is not adequate. I do not know where the figures came from and I do not really understand why they were introduced into this debate. I do not understand why Senator Crane would want to fly in the face of such concerted knowledge about what is adequate and what is sufficient in this particular area of Government expenditure.

The debate continued with, again, the predictable contribution that we quite often get from the coalition. I think that can only be summarised as being a stupid contention that this particular Democrat initiative cannot be supported because it will give advantage to more people in the city compared to people in rural areas. Of course it will. In case it has escaped the attention of the people in the coalition who accused us of dreaming up this idea, Australia is one of the most highly urbanised nations on this earth. Of course any move at all will have a greater effect on those who live in urban areas than those who live in the country, but those who live in rural areas of Australia who are disadvantaged by the present regulations will be more favourably advantaged by any removal of the assets test on Austudy provisions. In representing my State of Tasmania, I am well aware of the fact that Tasmania is the least urbanised of our States.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not enough room there for there to be anything else.

—I should take Senator Collins to Ringarooma and Bronte Park one day. Tasmania is not urbanised and removal of the assets test will be of particular advantage to those who live in Tasmania, or any other rural area which suffers from the inequities of the provision of an assets test to Austudy.

SPEECH.PARA: The assets test was described at some stage during the debate as `a battle of popularism' where people were trying to appeal to various segments of the electorate, and this followed on from the debate that there is a dichotomy between rural and urban. I disagree with Senator Reid that we are proposing a universal benefit. We are opposing the new regulations. The effect of that opposition is something which the Government inherits. When our activities threaten what the Government proposes or what the Government wants, we see it as the Government's role to continue its own fiscal responsibility and use the regulations which now exist, or which could be introduced or reintroduced at any stage by the Government.
I refer to a letter from the Clerk of the Senate who, when asked about the effect of the actions that we proposed, said:
There is nothing in the Act to prevent the making at any time of new regulations not the same in substance as regulations disallowed.

It is surely not beyond the wit or imagination of a government, if threatened by disallowance, to concoct new regulations which would have a similar effect but which would take into account the will of the Senate, the Parliament and, I suggest, the people. It is surely not beyond the capacity of a government to devise regulations which meet the needs that are expressed by a Senate which disallows previous regulations. It is also not a fact that the sky will fall in or that all chaos will reign if those regulations which we propose to disallow are disallowed. It should be within the capacity of the Government to meet that contingency if there is a sufficient threat that it might happen. That is the axis of this whole issue because the Government at no time has really believed that this will really happen. It was sufficiently strong in its belief that the faith of the Opposition to support it in this matter would not be shaken that no effort was made to devise regulations which would do the job better. It has complacently sat on its hands and said, `The Democrats will wave their arms in the air, nothing will happen and we do not have to try very hard at all'. That is a result of the Opposition's lack of real concern to see something decent resolved here.

We see a lot of crocodile tears from this Opposition and hear cries such as, `Oh, woe is the country', `Oh, dear, how terrible it is' and `Things are evil and things are crook', but when it comes to action, what do we see? We see faithful support of the Government, the excuse being, `We might not get everything right. There might be something a bit wrong and the Government really would not like to have its regulations upset'. I do not know whether that is accurate, but that is certainly the feeling I have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think cutting off Austudy--

—I am sorry; that is the feeling I have whenever I have to deal with the Opposition and ask that a challenge be put forward or that some action take place. But, no, we do not really get any action. Senator Crichton-Browne gave us a contribution, a fleeting contribution--
—If you could call it that.

—The Minister might be interested that, as I heard it, Senator Crichton-Browne suggested that the assets test was an equitable criterion. He then said that the level of income was declining and he gave figures to support that. He had the temerity to scream at the Democrats with information and anecdotes to support it as we sat here waiting. Senator Crichton-Browne stated our case and justified our desperation to do something. I waited for the `but' that often comes at the end of statements such as, `Yes, things are terrible; it is really bad', which would justify his inaction, but it did not come. But his inaction will come: his compliance with what the Government is proposing will follow on as predictably as it always does.

SPEECH.PARA: This notion that the Democrats cannot deliver and that it does not matter what our propositions are is only reinforced when we see the coalition refusing to consider some action. We can deliver; we have promised just now to deliver on Senator Teague's amendment, and we will when it becomes the subject of a matter of urgency or an urgency motion. We have promised that. Our initiatives are inaction only when the coalition refuses to act. It refuses to act on the grounds that there will be some huge cost visited upon the Australian taxpayer by our proposition.

Senator Lees has brought reality to that proposition. She has demonstrated in eloquent terms how, when it comes to the exercise of the Austudy option, even $26m is a generous accounting of the costs that could accrue from her disallowance motion. I suggest that, if the disallowance motion that I have proposed is considered and supported, the figures which were thrown around about the cost to the country are entirely fictitious because they do not pay regard to the reality of how this would work. We would not see the uptake of the sorts of horrendous figures that are postulated by the Opposition; we would not see a cost to the nation of that order. I suspect that, if double-counting is not involved, there is certainly not realistic counting of what offsets there would be.

In considering these regulations and proposing to disallow them, we have demonstrated their inadequacy and the huge change from the existing Austudy regulations, which, bad as they might be at the moment, at least do not visit upon spouses such a huge reduction of their allowable income from $18,000 to $12,000 and restrain the acceptance of tertiary places by so many people.

I will repeat the challenge: if the Government is conducting this review, the last thing we want to do right now is make Austudy worse. The Government could withdraw all the new regulations and persist with the old ones. If this review, which has not been well-aired but which has been described as being urgent and which is supported by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in its report on student finances, is in the offing, let us not make Austudy worse in the interim.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Hill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, to bring on a matter of urgency.

They said, `If the Opposition cannot support our disallowance motions, Senator Teague should move this as an urgency motion standing alone and you have our support'. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate calls on the Government to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from AUSTUDY by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.

I intend to speak on this matter for only a few minutes because, in my half-hour speech on the matter before us in the Senate this afternoon, I gave eminent reasons for the support of this urgent motion, which requires the Government to act immediately to meet the needs of families suffering in the rural crisis.

I note the speeches of more than seven Opposition senators in support of that proposition. Those senators were drawn from not only my own State of South Australia but also Queensland, Western Australia, the Australian Capital Territory, Victoria and I know that the same holds for Tasmania and New South Wales. Every part of Australia has at the moment families, some of whom have considerable primary production assets but who are receiving zero or negative incomes as a result of the tragedies of the present rural crisis. They are not in a position, as is contemplated by the current assets test, to sell off some of their assets. They are not able to use the assets they have to gain carry-on loans from banks for two reasons. The first is that in many cases it is not viable to dissect a portion of a viable property, whether it is an outback station or a mid-country farm, or whether it is in intensive horticulture. Secondly, they have not an income flow that would be able to maintain repayments on a loan even if a bank were otherwise to approve them for short term assistance.

In these circumstances there is a direct need in the rural crisis, as the Opposition has outlined today, for an exception to be made. We would see that exception as holding whenever there is a rural crisis. One senator referred to the earthquake in Newcastle as perhaps being another particular tragedy that might lead to particular Government emergency assistance or hardship provisions for a particular region. I do not want to argue the merits of further analogy or further example than the current rural crisis that we all feel so keenly.

I believe from my discussions in the corridors that there are Government members who are only too aware of the rural crisis. They are thankful that because of the pressure in the Parliament the assets test was liberalised beyond the onerous level that was imposed by the Budget decision last year. We are all thankful that reason was able to prevail with the Government to get that burden lifted for primary producers-for farmers-and for their families suffering in rural areas. We want that kind of immediate response from the Government answering an overwhelming vote in support of this motion here tonight in the Senate.

I referred earlier today to the statement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) reported today that he was bringing to the attention of farming families that there are hardship provisions under the Social Security Act and that these hardship provisions suspend the ordinary operation of the assets test. We want the Government to apply those provisions in a parallel way to Austudy so that we will have the outcome that the Opposition desires, that is, that no families whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis will be excluded from Austudy by the assets test, and that they will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.

I believe that this is not just a motion that will become a resolution of the Senate. It calls for action. If the Government does not act, it will hear about that on a continuing and increasing basis. It will hear about that from farming families suffering in the rural crisis. It will hear about it from the Opposition. I think the support we have gained from the Australian Democrats for this Opposition initiative tonight will mean that the Democrats also will press this point on the Government in the days to come.

We do not want just to win the numbers in a particular debate in the Senate. I impress on Senator Collins, on his advisers and on all other Government senators who are present in the chamber that the Opposition wants to see action and wants to see it direct and immediate. We do not support the abolition of the assets test as a whole. We believe in the targeting of Austudy to meet those in greatest financial need. We understand the consequence of the normal income test and assets test, and we ask that in addition to that the Government directly address the extreme financial circumstances currently being experienced by those who are suffering in the rural crisis. I hope that the Democrats will support this and that, by the Government conceding that this will be carried on the voices, we have the hearts and minds of Government senators behind us in support of this motion tonight. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did challenge the Opposition to bring forward as a motion the amendment which it had trotted out during the debate on the disallowance of various parts of the regulations for Austudy. I say `trotted out' because it seemed that it was a misplaced amendment in that debate. The temptation is to call it a fairly useless motion now because, as we observed during that debate, the amendment began by saying, `The Senate calls on the Government'. I will not waste the time of the Senate by repeating the feelings I had about the usefulness of the Senate calling on the Government to do something rather than forcing it to do things, as the Senate could have done had it supported our motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.PARA: However, let us look at some of the other things that are required to be done by this calling on the Government. The motion continues:
immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions . . .

There is no indication as to what sorts of provisions. It refers just to hardship provisions. There is no definition given to what is a hardship provision or what is hardship. In effect, in this motion we are trusting the Government to understand what the Opposition is thinking about here. Perhaps the Government has got the message but in essence what is being done by this motion is to trust the Government which claims that there already are hardship provisions. I contend that those hardship provisions demonstrably do not work, have not worked and cannot be made to work in the context in which the present Government gives it to operate.

While supporting this motion we would ask the Senate to call on the Government-and to trust the Government-to make hardship provisions. The Government, in fact, argues that it has hardship provisions, but we say that they do not work. So we are in a fairly vague situation already. I believe that the Opposition has moved this motion because, having done that, it is an excuse for not taking the difficult option of supporting Senator Lees's motion, at the very least, and for hiding behind the contention that a motion such as that put by Senator Lees would actually cost money. I suggest, though, that it is not so much a question of the money that it would cost. It is the priority that we ascribe to our educational needs that is under threat here, not so much the question of money being removed from another source. As was our contention during the debate, the money being referred to is not in the huge, frightening sphere that has been suggested by others. So, we see the excuse for the Opposition taking the option that it has, but I contend that it will have very little effect.

The Opposition has suggested that it wants to see the Government apply the existing provisions. That is a very strange assertion to make. A series of questions asked by myself and a number of other Democrat senators over a number of months has demonstrated that the existing provisions do not work. It is rather strange to suggest that we should apply something that does not work, and especially to trust the Government to introduce something that has not been accurately defined or delineated in any way. TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1991 (Hansard page 1132) Senator Short asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning comments by Senator the Hon. Peter Walsh on Australian fiscal policy in the 1980s. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The formulation of fiscal policy in recent years has been directed at the medium-term objectives of increasing public sector saving to ease pressure on the current account deficit and continuing the process of public sector reform to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of government programs and business enterprises. Senator the Hon Peter Walsh, in a paper titled ``Australian Fiscal Policy in the 1980s'', commented that ``it can be argued that the present recession is a function of fiscal policy being too loose''. That is a difficult argument to sustain given that total public sector outlays as measured by the Australian Bureau of Statistics fell by over 3 per cent in real terms between 1985-86 and 1988-89 contributing to a turnaround in the total public sector net borrowing requirement of over 6 percentage points of GDP from a deficit of 4.5 per cent of GDP in 1985-86 to a surplus of 1.7 per cent of GDP in 1988-89. The extent of the fiscal consolidation at the Commonwealth level over this period is currently being reflected in the maintenance of the Commonwealth budget surplus during a period of subdued economic activity.

In considering the choice of policy instruments to curb the recent economic boom, there is a need to have regard to the factors contributing to the boom. Real wage restraint over the period since the Accord resulted in falling real unit labour costs, contributing to higher profits and higher investment. In addition, increased government saving in the second half of the 1980s meant that there was a larger pool of domestic funds available to finance this investment. Other factors which encouraged investment in the recent boom were increased demand associated with an improvement in the terms of trade and a relatively high level of liquidity in the economy because of concerns about the 1987 stockmarket crash. Asset price inflation, in part driven by speculative elements, was an additional factor contributing to investment activity. Furthermore, part of the Budget surplus in recent years has been used to reduce personal income tax in order to obtain greater wage restraint, without which the economic slowdown would have been more marked.

In view of the overall strength of domestic demand, and the surge in private investment in particular, in the recent boom, the appropriate strategy was the one adopted by the Government; namely, to maintain firm fiscal policy settings and to tighten monetary policy.
